It was as if they had just cooked an inch of egg in a pan and then thrown the ingredients on top willy-nilly.  Overall, I believe the food is seriously about quantity and filling the plate to the brim for the surprise value, with scant afterthought given to how it is put together.  Particularly troubling for me was the lack of cheese and meat inside the omelet.

ENVIRONMENT/SERVICE: THREE STARS (* * *)
The environment is decidely no-frills, with an obvious shout-out to the diner days of yesteryear.  The map that adorns the wall complements the experience well (kitsh while remaining interesting).  The service I received was average and what you would expect at this price point--water refills, "hows the food?" etc.

VALUE: FOUR STARS (* * * *)
The one draw of the restaurant is that it certainly is a value.  A short stack of pancakes for only around $4 is hard to beat, especially in this city.  However, I am unwilling to give this particular category five stars (* * * * *) because I don't feel the quality of the food warrants it, even at these price points.  As I mentioned earlier, I feel to a large degree you are paying for bulk, and it certainly shows.

Average of
FOOD: TWO STARS
ENVIRONMENT/SERVICE: THREE STARS
VALUE: FOUR STARS
================
AVERAGED GRAND TOTAL: THREE STARS

Estimated price per person (excluding drink):
$9-12

Would I recommend it to others?
No.  If you are starving and in Lower Haight or if you want to see how many carbs you can get for your buck, check it out.  Otherwise, do some more research for other breakfast places.

Would I return?
No.  There are other breakfast places in the city that do a much better job on these types of classics for only slightly more money.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
Bacon Pancakes.  Say no more.

But wait!  There is more!  Kate's Kitchen makes Bacon Cheddar Pancakes, and they are made with an amazing half-cornmeal & half-buttermilk batter.  And, if you ask nicely, they will put walnuts in them!  I am in heaven.  Stick a fork in me, I'm done.

My hubby loves the French Toast Orgy, which truly lives up to it's name with lots of fruit, yogurt and granola goodness piled on top.  I have taken many a friend and out-of-town guest to Kate's and we've always had a great time.

One time...  we were waiting a while for our food, and we all remarked that it seemed a bit odd.  Then, the bill came.  Whoops!  Somehow, our order got lost.  Kate, a consummate hostess, immediately overheard the problem.  She brought us each a glass of orange juice to tide us over and cut our bill in half.  Now, that's how you handle service issues!  Kill 'em with kindness.  Thanks, Kate!

We'll definitely be back again and again.
author: J Liberty S.

description:
Went here with three other friends on a three-day mini vacation to SF. Found it on some traveler magazine thought it would be a tourist trap then Yelped it and saw all the great reviews. My visit that day was on point.

I didn't try the french toast orgy, which I regret. I always say order the unique/staple item on the menu. But I did try the Cornmeal pancake and hush puppies with pooh butter. Yum, everything was fresh out the kitchen.

I also got the Corn beef hash with potatoes. I wish they put a little more time into cutting the potatoes and veggies to appropriate size and uniformity, but who am I to ask that when the place was soo busy and they need to fulfill orders?

Anyways Kate's Kitchen, SF you were great!
author: Hannah Z.

description: I read the reviews that people gave this place regarding the service and I feel like they must have gone to another restaurant or something.  We went on a beautiful Sunday morning at about 11 am.   We had to wait about 30 minutes for a table.  Once inside the waitress was courteous (even after my spilling the cream on the table), quick to get our order, and kept the water n coffee flowing.   The food was really good American breakfast grub.  The potatoes were perfect and full of roasted garlic.  The homemade sausage brought out lots of 'mmmms' from the group.   Coffee was a little weird looking, but it was good.   The bacon was cut thick!
author: Diana D.

description: Food is fabulous - but the service is painfully lame --- borderline nonexistent.
author: Vicki L.

description:
I was hoping that my memory had just failed me, but upon returning to Kate's Kitchen, I was right the first time.

Their "famous" cornmeal hush puppies, are an overrated novelty item. Usually, I love hushpuppies and love love all things corn (lucky me, living in this hugely corn consuming USA).

Kate's were as bland as paper... even when I doused them in the tasty honey butter and salt.

The homey feel of the place was nice, but if you can't do right by fryin up a chicken apple sausage, hash browns (oddly overspiced), and dough balls with butter, you have no business being as popular as you are.  I guess it shows that the townies are so brunch crazed that all reason is lost after an hour wait.

And the service is very hit or miss - mostly aloof and unfriendly.
I don't need to be showered with accolades at brunch, but don't act like I've ruined your day just by existing.
author: Bamboo T.

description:
For Saturday brunch we barely had to wait for a table. The food options had creative names which were amusing, and we received our food promptly. The waitress was friendly enough and filled my coffee cup regularly.

Would have earned 5 stars if there hadn't been some invisible sticky substance on the table that I stuck my arm into. Oh and the music. The music was far too loud for a Saturday morning. I'm almost taking a star away just for that. But I won't. Cause I'm nice.
author: Lara L.

description:
It's 3pm on Saturday.  I'm awake.

No, not as in I've had a productive day and now I'll take this time to reflect, I mean I was asleep at 2:58pm and now I've managed to sleep off my hangover enough to wake up.

I'm a breakfast person.

I tell myself to stop this reflection and think fast.  I gotta have some breakfast and unfortunately places like to stop serving at 2pm or worse, noon.  

Kate's Kitchen is there for me.  

Kate's is a very serviceable brunch option and pretty key if, like me, you have a breakfast craving (they go until 3:45p on weekends).  They have a good amount of choices, including the cleverly named specials (the Tookie Williams Scramble was available for awhile in 2005) and they change every month or so.  Most of the plates usually come with enough food to soak up all the residual booze and fill you up good, especially if you split a side of pancakes (cornmeal or pumpkin, both are great) or hush puppies (very average) with someone.  The potatoes are actually pretty tasty, although they do give you like 5 pounds of them.   

This place should appeal to vegetarians (not vegans), as they usually have many meatless options.  (boo.)

The service here is usually solid which helps my headache go away quicker.  As with most places in the Lower Haight, it's great if you're in the vicinity, but probably not worth driving especially given the parking in Lower Haight.  

Just try not to eat so much you fall back asleep.
author: Steven R.

description:
Cool things about Kate's are:
-food is cheap
-servers are nice; seriously I've not encountered the "hipper than thou" attitude that others have found
-enormous portions
-my husband LOVES the homemade sausage

Not so cool things:
-the food is bland, dry, and greasy
-the coffee is mediocre
-they only take cash

Sorry Kate's!  I still sorta love you...at least when I'm hungover.
author: Jessica H.

description:
This place is a pretty good breakfast spot.  It is affordable and has a pretty nice menu (good options, not too much choice).  I ordered a bowl of fruit and some hashbrowns.  I was satisfied.  The people I ate with got the Big Guy's Breakfast, The French Toast Orgy, and the Fruit Orgy.  I deduced from the other diners around me that the portion sizes are HUGE (really, too big).  I correctly assumed that I would be able to cherry pick off of the left-overs of the others and didn't need to order a lot myself.  When we left at around noon on Sunday there was a big line to get a table (smaller line at 10 or 11).

The low down on the food itself: The fruit was good, hashbrowns not crispy enough and not enough spices, pancakes very fluffy but I prefer them more flavorful, french toast very good and unique (yogurt + fruit on top of the FT Orgy a bit of overkill), sausage tasted more like pizza sausage than breakfast sausage, bacon was better.
author: Adam M.

description:
Oh Kate, Kate
You're the one I'm thinking of
When I'm lonely and hungry
And my car has been broken in twice
Your coffee and bad attitude 
makes me happy inside.
author: Jon G.

description: I will go back to Kate's for brunch. The wait was kind of weird (signing up outside the door, random parties getting called in) but once we got in the servers were nice enough and all of the food was really good. You will want to stick with drinking water and coffee, but the pancakes and sausage were amazing. Everyone else seemed to like their food just as much as I did, too.
author: Shanna T.

description:
My friend and I went to Kate's around 12 or 1pm so we didn't have any problems getting a table.  

He ordered the french toast orgy which was delicious but enormous.  I had coffee, a cup of the soup of the day (which was some sort of spicy vegetable soup...very good), and the fancy grilled cheese.  There's nothing that I love more than pesto on my grilled cheese. 

It was simple and tasty although I can see why there are some bad reviews concerning their service.  The waitresses weren't the most friendly bunch but I didn't feel unwelcome.
author: Megan D.

description:
If you live around the Haight, you've probably dined in Kate's Kitchen - or at least have passed it. If you live in other neighborhoods, you probably rely on the breakfast goods from popular spots like Rose's in the Marina, Ella's in Lower Pac Height or Art's in the Inner Sunset. All are great spots and would likely earn a spot in the Hall of Fame as "Most Likely to Succeed on a Sunny Sunday" or "Most Likely to be Filled w/ Lacoste-clad men and Burberry-wearing women" or "Most Likely to Help You Gain Weight" - don't get me wrong. kate, however, is different from her colleagues. Not quite a hipster, definitely not a prep or "cool asian" (think "Mean Girls). 

Kate is a little different but definitely quality, generous, quirky and a good time.  Ordinary pancakes are jazzed up w/ cornmeal and a variety of topping options. My newest fav is granola and strawberries - 2 pieces piled with a ton of this good stuff is only $7. $2.50 for a couple pieces of THICK, delicious bacon and you've yourself a well balanced meal. Other things to try:

- hush puppies!
- the breakfast sandwich looked delicious
- corned beef hash is healthier than it sounds...piled high with potatoes, celery and carrots
- scrambles are filled w/ fresh ingredients but prob not the most innovative item
- yogurt, fruit and granola bowl - huge and healthy

Service is adequate, the top 40 music rocks and people are cool. Yup, Kate's got it going on...
author: Deann M.

description:
When I lived in San Francisco, Kate's Kitchen was close to my house and I only felt the need to eat there once.  The wait took forever, the food wasn't as great as I expected and seemed greasy, even for breakfast food that I expect to have a little bit of fat on it.  I should disclose that I ordered something with a fair amount of gravy on it and I'm not normally a fan of something that heavy in the AM.  

For awhile I felt like I should give Kate's a second chance but then I discovered Pork Store and totally forgot about it until happening upon someone's Yelp review.  It says a lot that I ate there months ago and never thought to Yelp the place.
author: Katie S.

description:
Oh wow. So if you ever wake up early on the weekend, this is a place to try. We got here before a line formed.

Started with everyone's recommendation: hush puppies with pooh butter. Pooh butter makes these EXCELLENT. You get 6 big balls of fried corn meal, nice and hot so it melts the honey butter.

I had the French Toast made from Texas Toast Wheat Bread with Strawberries & Bananas. You get 6 thick halves. Wowsers. ($8.00). The Orange Spice French Toast Orgy looked good too. A table nearby had it, and it came with a side bowl of yogurt fruit and granola. 

We also tried the Flanched Farney Garney (or something like that). Basically a Kaiser Roll with an egg of your choice, bacon or sausage and cheese. I recommend adding condiments (e.g. ketchup, salt/pepper) to liven this up.

There were many more items on the menu. The service is fast and efficient. The restaurant is small and fills up fast. Line starts forming at 9:30a. Not ideal for big groups. 2 or 4 is optimal. Hmmm!
author: Cindy W.

description: Went back recently and it seems to have gone downhill. Service was really slow and inattentive despite it being really empty that morning. Both of our meals weren't great either. My food came out lukewarm and sogged down with oil. My wife's pancakes were still alright. I'm sure I'll still be back again at some point, but was not impressed with my last visit.
author: Nicholas S.

description: Meh.  Not sure why so many people rave about this place.  I went a second time to see if maybe my first experience was atypical.  But, no. It was just as I remembered it.  Definitely not worth the wait.  I'm not a fan of their coffee - which is an essential part of brunch.  Service is not great.  The french toast was good but nothing special.
author: Lisa E.

description:
I have never been on the weekend.  I can imagine that the wait is dumb. the wait is dumb everywhere people!

This place is awesome.  It is cheap and the potions are gigantic.  The real kicker for this place is the homemade breakfast sausage.  It is really killer.  I mean.  To-die-for.  The big guy breakfast is meant for BIG GUYS.  I think it has eggs, potatoes, bread, bacon, sausage and pancakes.  Damn.  How could I eat all that?

If oyu find yourself with a weekday off.  Stop by Kate's.  It iwll do you good.
author: Thadd L.

description:
I think I'm actually pissed off at this place because everytime I walk down to Fillmore and Haight I look at this place with disgust.  Absolute disgust.  

I first visited Kate's Kitchen 2 years ago when I first visited San Francisco, and naive little me got off on the wrong stop and thought I was in the infamous Haight Ashbury District.  I stopped into Kate's Kitchen and had their red beans and rice dish.  I remember it being totally bland and boring.  And the greens tasted awful.  Fast forward to the other week when I've been in San Francisco for 2 years and now live and Lower Haight and decide to try Kate's a second chance...  

I order the French Toast and a side of bacon.  The waiter forgets to put my order in and after 20 minutes of waiting and watching everyone who arrived after me get there food, I ask the waiter where my food is and point out that the guy next to me came in 15 minutes after me and is now enjoying his meal and I'm not.  The waiter gets annoyed with me and tells me that he only ordered a fried egg sandwich which takes no time and I ordered the french toast...so...  Egg and bread?  vs.  Egg and bread?  I guess I just must have been missing something.  

Magically, my food comes out 6 minutes after I complain (kind of like he finally put my order in and they cooked it).  Anyways, the french toast was obnoxious.  6 large pieces of bland bread on my plate glistening with oil, with little egg, that didn't taste good with the syrup and tasted just ok with the strawberry jam.  I felt like I was being served glorified toast and there was enough bread there for 3 people!   Rude and incompetent service.  Bland food and obnoxiously large portions.  Not going back.

"Fool me once shame on.. shame on you... eh.. um.. a fooled man can't get fooled again!"
author: LaSha G.

description:
Kate's currently has 3.5 stars total and that's perfect. I've heard people rave about this place but I find it pretty good. Not super great.

Their corn pancakes are awesome as is the coffee. The biscuits always sound so good but they are kinda nasty. The vegetarian sausage gravy it comes with is f'in GREAT though. if I wasn't spoiled by the brunch places in LA, I'd possibly give this place 4 stars but I just can't do it knowing what the potential for a fantastic brunch place can be.
author: Chrissy Q.

description: Good healthy food choices.  Options available for breakfast gluttons too!
author: Oscar H.

description:
Okay, so what do you want in a Sunday Brunch? Does it have to be classy? does it have to serve hair of the dog? Or does it just have to taste good?

If you want BIG portions of GOOD tasting, anti-hangover food, Kate's will do you well. As with Dottie's you need to sign up, as this is a popular place. But, chances are once you get in and fail to finish your plate, you too will look at your bill and think, "Wha? It only cost THAT much???" 

It's not dotties... but it will do nicely!
author: Kevin R.

description:
This place was strikingly mediocre... reminiscent of what you'd get at a truck stop where the cooks didn't give a crap 'cause they knew that their cafe was the only place to eat for miles.

Only... this ISN'T the only breakfast place in town, so I'm *thoroughly* baffled why anyone would choose to eat here (it was a first -- and undoubtedly last -- visit for me and my friend).

First, let me highlight the good:
- The waitress.  Total sweetie... friendly, helpful, and attentive.
- The orange juice.  Seemingly fresh squeezed and chilled but not freezing cold.
- And... er, I guess that's about it on the good side.

The bad?:

- Hellishly noisy.  My friend and I could barely hear each other and we don't have hearing problems.  Well, at least we didn't before being subjected to this cramped echo'y place.

- Very bland, boring, totally uninspiring food.  Not even inspiring in that, "damn, that's nice and simple like my Grandma used to make" way. Syrup wasn't real maple syrup, potatoes were cold and mushy rather than warm, crispy and decently seasoned, omelette was boring, too.

- Cash only?  You've got to be kidding me.  If this were a cute and creative little mom'n'pop place in the middle of nowhere, I could understand, but a crappy diner-type place in SF?  Gimme a break.

I've had much better breakfast food when I cooked it myself, and -- believe me -- that's saying a lot ;)

P.S.  -- Forgot to add my gripe about the truly obnoxious portion sizes.  No, more is not always better.  I ordered the tall stack of cornmeal pancakes and the waitress (bless her heart) strongly urged me to order the short stack instead.  Let me tell you... even as a medium-sized and VERY hungry guy, I could barely eat one of the two huge-plate-sized pancakes.  I asked her if she had personally seen anyone finish the tall-stack... and she laughed and admitted that she'd only seen two folks manage it.  

Sheesh.  That's not good value (who actually takes home and reheats pancakes?  No, really!), that's just a disgusting waste of food.  Pity the Kate's folks can't concentrate on quality over quantity.
author: Adam L.

description:
Second time here and I dont think the breakfasts presentations is that great. A lot of food they give you but I feel like they just "pile it on" and its not something that good (they have thick bacon, potato hash, english muffin, and sausage".

 I came here again for the Cornmeal Pancakes but I gave in to eating "Egg" instead.  Not sure if I want to come back again.


-------------------


I came back here for a third time for the lack of finding a new place to try.  I got the french toast orgy this time and it was a whopping load of 6 slices of french toast toppled with granola/yogurt/fruits. I finished most of my fruit and yogurt.  My friends got the hush puppies too but I didn't try it.  Funny they use the term "pooh butter".  

It's crowded but I need to find a new place to try next time.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I had the big boy's breakfast (or something like that).  It came with 2 eggs, sausage, bacon, house potatoes, and 2 big cornmeal pancakes.  Everything was good.  The sausage patty stood out and had some nice flavor.  The pancakes were good, and I appreciated the generous size.  I don't know why they bring them out with such a tiny shot glass of syrup with it though. 

I also sampled some of my friend's corn hash, which was, surprisingly, a mix of potatoes, big pieces of onion, and carrots with a smattering of pieces of meat.  Not bad at all, but also not what I expected. 

If you go on the weekend, then you may have to wait.  Sign up on the  clipboard hung by the door.
author: David L.

description:
Went to breakfast here today with a friends and enjoyed the choices, the friendly wait staff and the good simple and well prepared breakfasts. 

They have egg white options, and hearty options. A great place for an American breakfast with creative pancakes, tasty french toast and good scrambles and omelettes.
author: Joe R.

description:
Just go.
Say yes, to trying it.
It's worth it...believe me.
Three words "French Toast Orgy."
Yes, it was as good as it sounds. 
The pictures on here are pretty accurate, the waitress was really nice, not to mention...pretty cute. Food was great. Coffee, was suprisingly, pretty decent. You know...when you see the lady come out with a pot of coffee to fill your ceramic cup at a restaraunt, you aren't really expecting much for flavor, but it was pretty great.
Good meal. Good price. Nice area [lower haight].
Thank you, to Kate, and your kitchen.
Try it out.
author: Ryan H.

description:
So many a hungover memory has been fostered at Kate's.  Love the food.  The specials are always splendid, with assortments of veggies in the omelettes that are inventive and tasty.  The hushpuppies and pooh butter are scrumptious.  And the french toast orgy is a delight, but only if you're the kind of person who doesn't mind having what is essentially three full meals stacked on top of eachother and set in front of you.  What keeps Kate from that elusive fifth star?  1. The gravy is no good.  2.  There's one waiter that thinks he's god's gift to front-of-house staff.  Newsflash, hotshot:  Aloofness does terrible things for your tip.

Oh, and a little sidenote to Charlie C:  I totally respect your food opinions, as they are, like mine, forceful.  However, overpriced?!  Are you high?  I say that b/c it's pretty much surrounded by dispensaries and thus a real possibility.
author: Casey S.

description:
Always a favorite for Sunday brunch but I went here on a Saturday this time. Only difference is that you have to pay for street parking.

I had the Big Guy Breakfast but I sampled my friend's corned beef hash too. It was no canned hash, it was homemade and delicious. My meal was um, big. Two eggs, bacon, home fries, something that looked like homemade sausage patty, and two giant pancakes. Very satisfying and a great value. The coffee was a bit strong and not in a dark roast sort of way but more in a "it's been sitting, baking, reducing" sort of a way. Nothing a little cream and sugar couldn't handle.

There can sometimes be a long wait and you need to sign the list outside the door then wait. Well worth it though. If you aren't that patient you can try Squat and Gobble around the corner.
author: Hunter G.

description:
Hipper than thou. 
Ridiculously long wait on weekends, because it's hipper than thou.
Pathetic "we are so entitled" service, because it's hipper than thou.
Extremely greasy and poor food, despite being hipper than thou.

Why even two stars?
Because it's cheap, portions are huge, it's deserted on weekdays (when the hipper than thou crowd is busy working in the financial district) and the hush puppie are actually good.
author: Tatjana G.

description:
Loved this place!
So much food for a great price  - which is hard to find in the city fro breakfast.  The  Big Guy Breakfast is fabulous - 2 HUGE (larger than your face!) pancakes (we asked for fruit on top), potatoes, bacon, two eggs any style, and sausage.
author: Catherine B.

description:
Four-star food plus huge portions equals five-star rating.

The first time I got the French Toast Orgy (one of the most aptly named meals I've eaten in my life), and the second time I got the breakfast scramble.

Very reasonable prices, and the homemade sausage is absolutely incredible. Either go here really early or really late on a Saturday or Sunday though, don't go between 9 and 11.


I often wonder if the 3.5 star-review is due to all the stupid hipsters who intentionally enjoy criticizing what everyone else likes.
author: Mark A.

description:
Who doesn't love Kate's??
I'm surprised to learn that, apparently, several people don't.

While it's not, like, *fancy* or anything, this place is excellent.  The map on the wall is endlessly entertaining for me (edutainment!), the pancakes are made with cornmeal, the French toast orgy is HUGE, the biscuits are great, even the sandwiches are very very good -- and everything is going to fill you up.  $9 at Kate's goes further than just about any place else in the whole city.

Forgive the naysayers, Kate's.  They know not what they do.
author: p m.

description:
Hush puppies.

I came here for the hush puppies.

They were not good.

The mural maps on the wall are very cool, but you can't eat them.
author: wayne s.

description: Just had the Cornmeal Pancakes with Strawberries,  Banana's and Lemon Zest. I definitely recommend this place if you want a sweet and savory morning bite in a relaxed and cozy atmosphere.
author: Annie J.

description:
I don't really get why this place has been popular for so many years. When I first moved here five years ago the fact that it was two doors down from me and was always really buzzing with customers made me want to try it and see what all the fuss was about. After going back three times (ordering different things each time) in the last five years I still don't get what the big deal is. The food is incredibly bland, I feel like I add tons of salt to everything which really isn't a good thing.

I will say that the staff is friendly and I really like the atmosphere but I can't really see myself going back for round four.
author: Allister F.

description: Absolutely loved it.  Only make sure you try one of their pancakes.  They put a complete breakfast in a pancake (even bacon) and they are TDF.
author: Kathleen C.

description: Ridiculously good food with a cozy atmosphere.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Tom F.

description:
Their corned beef hash seriously rocks. I always end up coming here in the middle of a weekday morning when there's hardly anyone here. I've been here enough to have deciphered the secret messages on the wall (too much coffee for me). It's a laid-back kind of place, service is not sharp, more relaxed, but it does the trick.

Hot sauce watch: Crystal (the best) and the usual Tabasco
author: Heather R.

description:
Kate's Kitchen is where you should go if your mom/dad/aunt/grandma didn't or doesn't know how to make breakfast.
I went twice, thinking that I must have had a bad egg or something on my first trip there. Everything tasted like slurm. It was like they had one pile of food in the back, and added different spices and gravy to different orders.
Now please... no offense to those of you who like Kate's Kitchen. I am glad you are there and not in my way or taking my table at a place where the cooking is a little more to my liking, being raised by two parents that knew how to cook.
author: Jason S.

description: Three of my girlfriends and I went to check out Kate's Kitchen for Saturday brunch.  The wait was very tolerable as it was only roughly 10 to 15 minutes at 11:30 AM for a party of 4.  I ordered the hashbrown special.  I thought it was delicious mostly because I love hashbrown.  However, it was really delicious because inside the hashbrown were eggs and bacon.  I guess you can't really go wrong when there's bacon involved.  My dish was $8.  I think coffee is also included so it's definitely a steal for brunch!  I don't say this often since there are so many spots to eat in the city but I would definitely go back.
author: Vicky C.

description:
I didn't like the coffee, potatoes and sausage. The oversized pancakes were good but I didn't like the little poppy seed size orange bits in it.
Eggs cooked over easy were overcooked for my husband, but perfect for me. Was it suppose to be made that way??
 Farmers Breakfast: $5.50
 Big Boy Breakfast: $8.25
To make the breakfast  experience worse, we ended up getting a parking ticket for parking on the street on street cleaning day, boo hoo!
author: Oanh N.

description:
Really, really crowded - but really good breakfast food, so it's worth the wait.

The hush puppies with pooh butter (honey butter) are sublime and since there are about 6 in the order, they can be shared with brunch companions - or kept all to yourself.

As Kellie P. mentioned, the French Toast Orgy is insane.  It looks like Caligula on a plate.  I'm sure that it's really good, but I'd rather have the orgy part served separately from the French Toast.

Their pancakes are really good, the corned beef hash is also delicious (and recommended) and the homemade ginger ale is worth a try.  And I agree - the biggest drawback is no soy milk.  So you're left with either bringing your own drink, or bringing a small carton of your own soy milk.
author: Carly P.

description: Came here on a Weds morning and there were only like 2 other parties in the whole place. WORST SEVICE EVER!! The server sat in the corner and ate her breakfast while we waited 40+ minutes for ours - and my coffee cup was DRY. This is a big ol' breakfast no-no. From the kitchen came blaring heavy metal music - I'm taking blaring - we couldn't hear each other speak.  Not being a heavy metal fan myself - especially not at 8:30am in a restaurant - this was a huge turn off. That waitress seems oblivious to the fact that she's providing customer service & working for tips. Definitely won't ever go back
author: Jill S.

description: I grew up in West Virginia and I know biscuits and gravy. This place would have closed down there in their first week with their interpretation of biscuits and gravy. The biscuits were rock hard sitting in a completely flavorless gravy. You really have to try to make biscuits and gravy this bad. I don't understand any of the positive reviews of biscuits from this place. Those people must not understand what biscuits are suppose to taste like. Biscuits /= rocks. Yuck. I'm not even going to start with the collard greens. WARNING to southerners and country folk: stay away.
author: Di L.

description:
Let me make this simple so that it will be impossible for you to fail in your brunch adventure to Kate's (and as a result give this awesome place anything less than a 5 star rating):

1. Go early - you'll avoid the lines.
2. Order coffee - the coffee here is my second favorite in the city (can't beat Philz).
3. Order orange juice - fresh squeezed and yummy.
4. Order the flannel hash - don't look at anything else on the brunch menu. you want the flannel hash. it's the best damn corned beef hash in the city.
5. Thank me.
author: Tal K.

description: My GF and I are vegetarians so I can't speak for the meat dishes here but our veggie food was pretty disappointing. I had the French toast; soggy and generally blah.  The fruit orgy was the best thing we ordered although the yogurt was lacking. Coming in third, or perhaps more appropriately, last place, was the veggie biscuits and gravy. The biscuits tasted okay but the gravy was almost flavorless. It honestly tasted like it was just veg oil with some flour and chopped mushrooms. No salt. No veggie sausage. No taste. No thank you.
author: Andrew W.

description: I did NOT have a favorable experience here, and am really only give it 2 stars for location and that it is one of the few places open for breakfast...that being said, I still would not return.  I ordered the egg sando with cheese and sausage and if McD's can make a decent egg sando, than so should Kate's...well, the cheese was barely there and the eggs were sliding out of the bread.  When biting into the sausage all I could taste was nasty little niblets of grissel and an overpowering fennel taste.  Also the temperature inside the establishment was so hot I felt like I was going to pass out.  Please Kate, fix your kitchen!
author: Jessica B.

description: The guy that waited on us this morning was the worst. We were told by him to sit anywhere and we chose a large table. The two of us liked the extra room since there was plenty of open large tables. The waiter immediately said you can't sit there and threw our menus down on a tiny table next to the kitchen. We switched and as we sat and waited asked how we were but didn't give us a chance to talk as he wizzed past us. So rude! This is the first time I walked out of a restaurant. I love the food for the price but won't be returning now until the service is good again.
author: Tracy T.

description: I really liked Kate's. Was by myself and got seated pretty quickly- there usually IS a line out front. Great, accommodating, friendly staff, food was standard breakfast fare, well done and quite reasonably priced. Busy, a little loud, fun, good people watching. I would definitely go back.
author: JOHN S.

description:
Much love for Kate's!

I seem to find myself bringin nearly all my out of town guests to Kate's.  It's always the first on my lists of places to send people when they are looking for something new.

Their coffee is delciously rich!

And with a little twist on some classics
such as the orange zest french toast!
Meatloaf sandwich
and Bacon Cheddar Corn Cakes
you can't go wrong and even the pickiest eater will find something to enjoy on this menu!
author: Mother L.

description: Dry bacon, small portions, bland food, cash only. What is there to like?
author: Tony T.

description: I wanted to love Kate's Kitchen.  It had all the usual fixings of a good breakfast/brunch spot: a long line, unique interior (sweet USA mural), friendly waitresses, and a simple, but tempting menu.  All in all though the food was just decent.  I might be tempted to go back and try something else, but I would probably just go elsewhere.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Its pretty simple really. After waiting for about a half hour for a table, a group left that would've seated the party of three that I was in and we were next in line. we were excited. Unfortunately, 3 minutes before they left a group showed up that knew the host, and after they put their name down on the list, were quickly ushered inside to what was suppose to be our table. When we said something about being skipped, the host assured us that we would be seated soon. we were no longer excited.

we went to home and had a much tastier meal. 
and you know what? the potatoes are always awful at kate's anyways. and if you eat their sausage, you will burp it for the rest of the day.
author: Nate R.

description:
Finally got a chance to check this place out. The occasion...my old high school friend was visiting from NYC, I had Monday off work and we earned it by staying up drinking whiskey till 5am ;-)

Fortunately for us Kate's serves breakfast 'till 3pm. Yea!

I order the "big boy" or something like that. The dish came with two eggs, two strips of bacon, sausage patty, and cormeal buttermilk pancakes.  

I order my eggs overeasy and they came out perfectly...goopy yellow centers..mmmm! The cornmeal pancakes were really tasty. I like the extra texture the cornmeal adds to the pancakes. 

The place is a bit dingy, the bathroom is no exception, plus the fact that you have to walk thru the kitchen to get to it. Overall the food was good, but given the choice I'd probably head to the Pork store. 

I'm givin' 3.5 stars. I will be back to try the French Toast Orgy, it looks tasty.  Plus this place is like a 5 minute walk from my place, serves breakfast till 3pm and it's a good bargain for the amount of food you get.

Now if I could only find a good local brunch place that serves Bloody Mary's too!
author: isaias J.

description:
I love coming here for a little down home brunch. My stars almost entirely go to the following: 

--Both of the fruit/yogurt/granola concoctions are amazing and well worth their inexpensive price.
--The green onion and cheddar biscuits are also delicious, as well as their hush puppies.
--They also serve a delightful cup of OJ
--Ambiance/people watching is never disappointing

It pays to come a bit earlier, as the line can get a little out of control.
author: Alicia J.

description:
Aside from the generously-sized portions and the kindness of the people running the place, Kate's would have received two stars from me solely on the basis of food.  Although I did enjoy eating there with my girls for a late Friday brunch, and the French Toast Orgy was definitely a winner in my book, everything else just wasn't up to par.

Dining with fellow Yelpers Angie B. and Natalie M., as well as another foodie gal pal of ours, we entered a completely full restaurant and were seated in the back, right near the entrance to the kitchen.  Our server (GO BEARS) was sweet and always handy but she did manage to drop Angie B.'s syrup on the floor.  Anywho...

As a self-proclaimed corned beef hash princess, I had to give my order both good and bad points.  Seasoning was spot on, but there was sooooo much more red potato and vegetable than corned beef that I felt like I was forced to ration my meat throughout the duration of the meal.  Otherwise I would have finished at least a good 20 minutes before the other ladies did.  Eggs were cooked to perfection though.

Angie B. proudly requested, then proudly shared, the aforementioned French Toast Orgy and it was delicious.  I can't say anything negative about orange spiced anything.  Yogurt/granola/fruit combo was definitely a great pairing, and just a touch of syrup made this a great morning meal.  Natalie M. got the special omelette of the day and I LOVED IT for its unabashed display of garlic heaven.  Our fourth food lover ordered the 9-grain oatmeal and although it was pretty good for being her 'detox' meal, it still was what it was...  9 grains which were pretty distinctly tasted.

Coffee was so-so, owner (operator?) personally brought me strawberry jam in the absolute kindest manner possible which REALLY impressed me.  Overall I'm sure this joint can boast of better food, but until then, I'll just keep indulging in my Orgy, thank you.
author: Monica D.

description: I don't understand why the quality here has slowly gotten worse. The homemade sausage is now the driest you'll ever taste, and the potatoes are simultaneously both burned and undercooked.
author: Adam Z.

description:
I just had brunch at Kate's and still, 2 hours later, can't decide if I liked it. On weekends I go out to eat with my friends after running. This morning, we did 16 miles, so we had worked up enough of an appetite to sample a good portion of the menu. One of my friends got Kafka's scramble (veggies and eggs), while the other basically ordered 5 side dishes and mixed them together on one plate. The waiter looked at him strangely, but was accommodating of his bizarre tastes. I got the corned beef hash. and some hush puppies.

My friends seemed to enjoy their meals, but the hash was definitely not what I was hoping for. I like my hash to be chopped up pretty well -- this was SUPER chunky, with some hunks of corned beef that were maybe 1" cubes. That's a pretty big cube of meat if you think about it. The hush puppies were delicious, mostly because of the (apparently legendary) pooh butter. I would almost consider getting 3 orders of these and making a meal of them, but I'm pretty sure my stomach would hate me later.

We had to wait a little bit, but that seems to be pretty standard for any decent brunch place on the weekends. Service was pretty good, though the waiter said he could bring us some orange juice outside while we waited for a table and never followed through. The whole experience was very reminiscent of the Pork Store Cafe, which, oddly enough, is about a mile up the same street. I'm sure that there are some dishes that this place does better than Pork Store, but certainly not what I had. 

Bonus points for the woman standing outside her house down the block cheering me on as I parallel parked in a tiny space. She totally made my day. A tip for first-time patrons of Kate's Kitchen, courtesy of my friend Matt: "You want to maintain a good rapport with the woman in the projects who knows where you parked your car."
author: Derek S.

description:
Mmmm... breakfast all day. Great coffee. Crazy people outside. The waiter was a little unfriendly. Somehow forgetting to give us utensils was a humanizing experience for him and he became a lot nicer. 

I got the corned beef hash which has big chunks of potatoes, onions, carrots and corned beef. Drop some eggs on top and some bread on the side and you're golden. It was a good deal at $8.50 but not a culinary masterpiece.

I'd probably go back if I were sticking around San Francisco and hope for a friendlier experience next time.
author: Colin N.

description:
The corn beef hash is out of control amazing, but don't expect it to look like canned hash - 5 stars

The egg sandwich and home fries are average - 3 stars

We got there at 9am on a Sunday and there was no wait, but by the time we finished eating people were lining up outside.
author: Corinne R.

description:
One bite of Kate's pumpkin pancake and I knew I had found THE place for a tasty pit stop on a brisk morning motobike ride. I fired up the twin-V, flew out of the bat cave and then grabbed a sweet and knowledgeable local. We rode through the chilly winter air into a bright sun warming the hills above Hayes Valley. She said there are other places that are "decent" choices too as we watched the food hit the table only minutes after we ordered. Yada, yada is what I started to hear as I bit into a light yet dense, moist yet airy, cake from the griddle covered in honey butter and real maple syrup. No need to hear about other spots; this one is super. I was carried off into the legend of Paul Bunyan and the Blue Ox! That cake was gone faster than you downshift a fixie. 

Oh, the corned beef. Cubes of fatty and stringy goodness. This is a real corned beef hash, not the typical mash you'll find in most diners. My vegetarian companion insisted I give it a try. I could tell she was conjuring up memories from years ago -- it's that kind of flavor combination. The carrots had a subtle sweet taste that can only come from freshness, while the onions and peppers were softened yet retained their bite and crispiness. Potatoes were hot, soft and with skins. Big portions. 

My only complaint is that the front door is far, far away from the mountains. 

Heh, and the solution to the giant art (long cypher) on the wall should be easy if you own a cell phone. It's text messaging format. 4u = for you, 1DR=wonder, etc..
author: Mulberry S.

description: The wait can be a pain. Get your name on the list, go get a Turkish coffee at Cafe International and come back. The Corn Beef Hash is royal.
author: Paul C.

description:
I was made a very happy girl Saturday morning when my sweetheart agreed to stopping for breakfast the rainy day after Halloween. 

Note* there is an actual wait list posted outside the door. Sometimes people miss this and newcomers get seated first. 

After my last experience with the delicious French toast orgy, I decided I should probably go with something lighter, so I ordered the fruit orgy (ok, still a lot more than one person should eat in a single sitting). All the same fruit/yogurt/granola/honey goodness but without the sinfully fantastic French toast. 

Coffee is mediocre (there were a few grounds in the bottom of my cup, truth be told). 

On the way out, I noticed a spectacular-looking large biscuity thing balanced on the edge of a plate one table over. Turns out my keen eyesight did not deceive, it was, in fact, a biscuit. So, I did what any self respecting girl who'd just forgone the French toast in favor of a healthier breakfast should do and ordered a biscuit to go. It arrived, probably 10 minutes later (I think the waitress forgot). It was hot, flaky, cheese and green onion flavored goodness. I'll be back to try all those indulgent menu items I've neglected thus far and enjoy the fruit orgy again.
author: Angela N.

description: Just incredible pancakes, and very generous servings.  The bacon however was a little over done and the line could be long--but again, worth the wait for the strawberry banana topped cornmeal pancakes.  Great hash & potatoes, I'd definitely go back again--it's kinda necessary when all I could think about is the food there...
author: Heatherly H.

description:
The Mecca of cheap plentiful breakfasts. A lot of food for a very cheap price. The Big Guys Breakfast will give you two large pieces of sausage, two super long pieces of bacon, breakfast potatos, eggs, and two large pancakes. WOWza. All for $9.75 which includes tax.

Ambience is a little plain but considering there are meals for $5-7 I think the decor is plenty fancy enough since they are catering the lower haight crowd and people wanting to wear t-shirts and jeans. Although I swear I saw multiple guys wearing only wifebeaters and it was freaking cold outside.

Serving staff was quick and polite. Large specials menu.
author: Mike T.

description: I really love this little breakfast place. It's a great price for a yummy breakfast. I usually order the Lauren special or the vegetarian sandwich, just recently tried their hashbrowns with bacon and scrambled eggs, everything is always really good. My friend had the French toast and hush puppies. He loves their jalapeño jam and the honey butter that comes with it. They just added a fresh juice menu. We tried blueberry apple and it was good. The staff are always nice and remember us everytime we come back. Only downside is it's small and squishy in certain areas.
author: stephanie w.

description:
Yum, this menu is more than a couple steps above the greasy spoon. Sure, it's pricey, but you're paying for sweet service and tastier bites. Everything tastes fresh (and it is?). I especially love the pancakes with strawbs, bananas, and lemon curd (who needs syrup?!). Seriously, try the lemon curd. Sick name, I know, but it's great. The fried potatoes are delicious too - not overly oily, nice and crunchy. 

The wait can be killer if you go on the weekends because you'll usually hit the hungover crowd. Otherwise, it's not too much of an issue if you pick the right hour to dine.

Cash only, and you might need more than the 20 you just pulled from the nearby ATM.
author: Brittany L.

description:
I go there when I crave biscuits and gravy. Its more of a sausage thing I guess, biscuits & sausage gravy. Sausage on the side. I can't explain it.

Not worth the wait. If you're in the mood for this kind of average din, then stop in if there is no line.
author: Marz W.

description:
Like most 9-5ers, I look forward to going out for brunch every weekend. In San Francisco, I've become accustomed to grabbing a coffee before writing my name on clipboard, and braving a long line before settling in to eat.

Kate's Kitchen is among my top ten favorite brunch spots in the SF. Your choices run from savory to sweet, and sometime feature a combination of both (cheddar on pancakes with bacon). 

Always order the Hush Puppies and get a side of honey to go with 'em. I'm a fan of the French Toast Orgy - it has "orange & spice" infused bread with fresh fruit, vanilla yogurt, homemade granola, and honey. It is amazing.
author: Chris I.

description:
I have been here 4 times and each time I have been disappointed.  The food just seems like it is all thrown in a pan and then plopped on your plate.  The coffee is good and the scrambbles are creative, but I have never been impressed by their offereings.  Burnt toast, cold potatoes and hardly cooked eggs.

2 stars because of the hushpuppies and poo (honey) butter...
author: Julie C.

description:
Consistently a good breakfast.  I'm a big fan of the corn-meal pancakes and when totally starving, I get the "Big Guy's Breakfast", which is a ton of food, and I'm usually full until dinnertime.  The specials are usually good, too.

When I lived in Lower Haight I remember the wait to get in being epic, kind of like Pork Store on a Saturday or Sunday morning, but lately the lines haven't been bad at all and two people can get in pretty quick.  The service has always been friendly and prompt.

One tip - the breakfast potatoes here aren't the best in town (in my opinion) - the hot setup is to get the very generous bowl of fruit instead of the potatoes.  Very good.

There is always music playing there, which is cool, but a few times it has been deafening - not so cool.  

Breaky for two is usually around $20-ish.
author: Doug M.

description:
It's all about the hushpuppies with pooh honey butter.  I don't know where else to get them.  Even so, these are probably better.  Get them.  They are a deal and filling and so amazingly good.

Otherwise, this place is above average.  They have amazing specials.  Good for vegans, green folks, etc.  Lots of choices.  Coffee is good and strong.

Warning: This place gets extremely crowded and loud and you will have to wait outside a long time if you come at the wrong time.

The only take cash as well.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Went with friends early last Saturday morning so we did not have to wait in line. Let me tell you at 9:30am you can easily get a table, Around 10am is when it starts filling up. 

Ordered hush puppies while we decided. The honey butter was great and made up for the fact that the hush puppies size was too big to allow for the proper fried cornmeal flavor. 

I got the biscuits in gravy. When I lived in New Orleans Chicken fried steak with biscuits and gravy was one of my breakfast faves. Now I realize California is far more health conscious than New Orleans but the gravy tasted like corn chowder rather than white gravy. If you are going to make southern style gravy you can't use vegetables. Enough Said.  Additionally I am not sure how they managed this but the grits were sort of watery...and cheese grits was not an option on the menu.   Grits with out cheese is like peanut butter with out jelly. 

The space was cute and our servers were really pleasant, did not rush us, and continually filled up our coffee/water. I would probably try this again for more California styled brunch cuisine. But won't go in with the hope of authentic southern soul cooking.
author: Courtney R.

description:
Solid breakfast and lunch joint. I eat here when I'm working from home but never on the weekends, just too crowded relative to food quality.

I mean it's good, but not worth waiting in line for 30 minutes over. Coffee is subpar. But the breakfast deal on weekdays ain't bad. I think it's 5 bucks for coffee and basic egg-related breakfasty items. Unfortunately, it's kind of embarassing to have to say "rooster booster" or "flanched farney garney" in public. Also, places that serve breakfast on weekdays should seriously consider being open before the crack of 9am.

If you choose to brave the crowds on weekends or stray from the, um, rooster booster, the pancakes are really good and HUGE portion. Hush pups are delish as well.

Sometimes I see Supervisor Ross Mirkarimi in here for breakfast. Shouldn't he be at City Hall or something?
author: Josh K.

description:
I love Kate's kitchen! They have very affordable, delish brunch (that is all I ever go there for) but the lunch looks yummy too. 

I highly recommend the French Toast Orgy. It is so big it's a good idea to split it w/someone OR have them box up half of it for you to take home or give to a homeless person as you walk home/catch the bus/walk to your car. 

The parking isn't bad but it is easily accessible by public transit (close to the Church St. muni station & bus lines). 

You will likely wait on a typical weekend but there is a list you can write your name on & it gives you lots of time to read a book or visit w/your friends while you wait. I think I've typically waited 20 minutes plus for a table for 2, not bad really. 

They are really nice & have great service when I've been there. I can't wait to go back again!!
author: Abby W.

description:
What is the big deal here?  

A worn, noisy interior and really average food.  The hash was nothing special.  We had to ask for butter for the toast.  There was only one kind of jam on the table.  Maybe the pancakes are better.

Our waitress disappeared and was seen chatting in the kitchen.  We had to flag down another one to finish up and bring the check.

Yes, it is cheap, but unless you are stuck in the lower Haight, you can get a lot better food nearby at Chow or Stacks for not much more money.

Oh, and bring cash.  They don't take cards.
author: Alan B.

description: This place is great. I keep hearing of long lines but have yet to really wait more than 10 minutes. The food is great and inexpensive. The service is awfully friendly.
author: Jerry S.

description: I hanker after their Flarney Barney or whatever it's called. Perfect hangover food. One of the hosts there is a total b**** and the rest are somewhat friendly at best. Still, the food is copious and cheap, if that's what you are looking for. No mimosas, either. Very crowded.
author: Mi M.

description: Hush puppies were the bomb. Eggs were greasy. Not hung over enough to enjoy that. Haha..  Staff was fast and nice. My girl friend looked great.
author: Justin B.

description: Flanched Farney Garney is awesome for a hangover, but aside from that, I think my tastebuds have evolved since college. The fruit is mealy, and the quality is pretty poor...not to mention, eh, not the cleanest.
author: Brittany T.

description:
best cornmeal pancakes ever! 

you feel very in the know about hitting up this spot. not a huge menu, but everything they make is delish! 

excellent location too
author: jaclyn g.

description: Pretty yummy veggie scramble, but nothing to rant and rave about.  Comfy, not over priced, and the menu has some potential for a better review next time.
author: Kacie O.

description: Solid breakfast for $6.  I couldn't believe my eyes when I saw menu items for $5.95.  Eating at the likes of Dottie's and such, I forgot that breakfast should probably cost that much.  $2.50 for a tall glass of OJ.  Hallelujah.
author: Wakako U.

description:
The price is right, the food is straight forward & decent.  Strong coffee that kept coming  was above par.  I went for the French toast which met my high french toast standards.  though after all the hype i've heard....it wasn't anything groundbreaking.  

*I was with my friend & her 3 month old, so the place gets massive kudos for going the extra step to accomidate us.  it ain't always easy in this city w/ a baby in tow*
author: Liz V.

description:
Casual, yet non-generic is the perfect description for this hole-in-the-wall brunch place.  The orange-flavored french toast is killer.

Wow.  Could my description BE any more detailed?
author: Momo R.

description:
I used to go here a lot when I lived down the street. I was initially attracted to it, because there's always a crowd of people outside the tiny establishment on weekends for brunch.

I will say that I think it's over-hyped. The meals are OK, but not much more. The thing that stands out about Kate's is their portion sizes, which are ginormous -- honestly, too huge for single servings.

The place itself hasn't been updated in a long time and lives up to its hole-in-the-wall image, but in terms of food, I think Kate's could do a lot better.

In hindsight, I realize I went to Kate's more out of convenience than anything else...now that I'm no longer in the neighborhood, I never find myself there or craving to go.
author: Joyce S.

description:
This place was pretty decent.  I had the uniform California sandwich or grilled chicken and avocado.  The sandwich was tasty--no complaints.  

I am absolutely dying for their ginger ale, though.  It's made in-house, of real ginger, and quite on the spicy side.  This is nothing like canned ginger ale, so be prepared for a completely different taste.  Go against convention and get something different on the menu.  I am not a San Franny resident, but if I were and lived in the Haight area, I would attempt to buy their ginger ale by the bottle.
author: Molly F.

description:
Loved Kate's, very homey feel...the server was prompt and friendly and constantly made sure we had fresh hot coffee, which was surprisingly good.  They make their own cornbeef and hash and the texas toast is really light but filling and the maple syrup just makes everything mmmmm mmmm good.  Thanks to Kates for turning around a crappy start and making my tummy full and my coffee needs met!
By the way, if you are looking for some serious pancakes, I spotted another diner having them, and they are as large a small child.....they looked FANTASTIC
author: Kathie C.

description: Consistently good food. Come early to beat the late-rising Lower Haight denizens.
author: Rennie S.

description: Ya, I've been going to Kate's for over a decade now, I guess I should put in a review. They are plane and simple, delicious. Usually the service is good, even though they are always taking about 12 tables at once. It's loud in here. It's unavoidable, the kitchen is like an unnatural amphitheater. The food makes up for it though. Everything is good, you can count on it. Not everything is a knock your socks off good, but it's always delicious. Even the eggs are good here, and I don't like eggs. I live kate's, it's dependable and homey and just plain comfort food for cold cloudy days in SF.
author: Jordan P.

description: I have been trying to get in here for brunch for more than 10 years and always gave up because of the long lines out the door.  But I was walking by after my haircut the other day and saw a bunch of tables free, and walked right in and was seated right away.  And I was blown away by the home cooking!  Wish I had gotten in here earlier....this was the best breakfast I've had at a restaurant in years.  The ingredients are wholesome, and you get a real home-cooking touch.  Not too pricey either...good stuff and if I can manage to get in without waiting in line again I won't wait 10 years.
author: Vivek A.

description:
3 words: French Toast Orgy.

Need I say more? No, but I will.

Texas toast in an tasty orange-vanilla batter then fried to perfection. Fruit salad with all kinds of fruit I would never have thought to put on toast. Yogurt and granola. It's amazing. It's a party. It's an orgy.
 
As an added bonus, Kate is a total sweetheart.
author: SteveTwentyThree S.

description: Came here on a Sunday for a hungover brunch at 11:15 and had to wait about 15 minutes for a table, not too bad. I ordered the Farmer's breakfast with 2 scrambled eggs, potatoes & whole wheat toast for $5.50, you can't beat the price. The food wasn't anything amazing, but for how cheap it was, it was awesome. I liked the potatoes a lot, good flavors. Friendly service, small tables that were a little crowded, but I am not going to complain. I left full, happy & still had a few dollars cash left over! (cash only)
author: Elaine S.

description:
Corned beef hash was underwhelming. Potatoes and carrots were bland. Corned beef was okay. The poached eggs were done well.

The only item that was tasty was the house made jam/syrup. The strawberry was perfect - not too sweet, not too tart. 

Service was spotty. Drinks were refilled quickly without asking, but it took forever to get a bottle of hot sauce.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
Decent breakfast and coffee....but  I'll risk offending the sacrosanct breakfast institution that is Kate's Kitchen...because as a big fan of breakfast potatoes I am consistently disappointed by the mushy potatoes*...So much so that as my place straddles Hayes Valley and the Lower Haight I am more likely to turn toward Hayes Street for my leisurely Sunday brunch than toward the Haight.  

*Thing is, you don't want to fully cook the potato...you want to make it *tender* and then add it to a hot skillet.  I know, I know -- why don't I just stay home and cook myself some breakfast potatoes?  Because I'm lazy.
author: G. B.

description:
For a long time, Kate's Kitchen was that place in town "where everyone knows [my] name," to paraphrase the theme from 'Cheers'.  

When I was working as a waiter at another restaurant, I ate breakfast at Kate's at least twice a week.  Always the same order:  Farmer's Breakfast, scrambled, whole wheat toast, sub fruit (i.e., fruit instead of potatoes), coffee and water.  I didn't even need to order after a while -- it was great.

Now, though, when I can usually only go on weekends, the long wait for a table is frustrating, and the consistency of the food seems more variable than it used to be.

Basically, Squat & Gobble around the corner wooed me away.

Still, Kate's can be great for what it is: a funky (nearly iconic) and inexpensive breakfast place.  It's still my girlfriend's favorite local spot.  Definitely check it out.
author: Doublejack X.

description:
I had a pretty good scramble with jalapenos and veggies.  Tried my friends cornmeal pancakes with granola and strawberries which were good, but not the sweet breakfast treat i expected when i reached for a bite.

Coffee cups are pretty small, but the refill often enough.

They lose points for trying to  seat 4 of us awkwardly at table where 2 of us were facing a wall when there were two other large tables available. We asked to switch and the hostess gave us A LOT of attitude about it, which was not cool.
author: ALEXIS B.

description:
Of all the breakfasts in the Lower Haight, this one is my favorite:

The Big Guys Breakfast (slightly modified)

- Cornmeal pancakes (the bomb)
- Thick-ass bacon
- Un-cased sausage (good, but could be spicier)
- Two eggs
- Potatoes (which I sub for fruit)

It's a lot of food, but it usually keeps me good 'til din-din.  Subbin' the fruit helps.  They also have real coffee... strong.

This place keeps it real.  You won't find Equal or that yellow stuff here.  It's the Lower Haight, dammit; this place hasn't forgotten that.

I've had the other selections on the menu; they're all good.  I keep going back to the Big Guy's, though.
author: Stephen B.

description: The service was great, but the food was really bland. I was missing some really strong flavors, or something to make my taste-buds dance. We got the Biscuits and Sausage Gravy and the Pancakes and split them.
author: Tim L.

description:
Went to Kate's Kitchen this past weekend for brunch, which I was thoroughly looking forward to since I never eat breakfast, but was thoroughly disappointed.  I ordered the cornmeal buttermilk pancakes, and the cornmeal just killed it.  The pancakes were not warm at all and had a pile of granola covering the pancakes, a horrible attempt at presentation.  

The place was fine, the service was fine, but nothing special.  Basically it came down to the food and after tasting a few of their plates (a bit here and there of their french toast and veggie spramble) I basically ended up regretting my decision to go there for breakfast.
author: Sarah I.

description: Had an omelette with shrimp and peppers... I think it was called across the border or something; tasty enough. Some of my potatoes (home fries) were burnt, and the wheat toast was good. Also had a lemonade spritzer, which made me with I had a flask of vodka with me. Cashola only.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Very good oatmeal, hush puppies, homeade sausage, and potatoes. Wait staff was friendly and attentive. The only cons were the long wait and it's not the best place for small children... Would go again...
author: P T.

description:
OK, so my boyfriend and I tried this place at random on our recent visit to SF.  When we walked in the one waitress was eating and let us seat ourselves-ok that's unusual...  Service overall was slow as the place got busier.  I had the "orange spice" french toast, that tasted just like regular french toast. It was ok but they give you a half filled tiny condiment cup of syrup and the waitress never came back in order for me to ask for more. My boyfriend's biscuits and gravy were just gross.  Flavorless lumpy gravy (supposed to be sausage gravy but tasted like straight flour) all over some not so good biscuits.. it amazed us how a biscuit with so many ingredients- dill, chives, i think i even saw yellow cheeze bits- again had no real flavor other than weird and stale.  Our coffee and water was never refiled, the only time we saw the waitress again was when she swept by to drop off the check. Oh and come to find out you have to walk through the open kitchen to get to the bathroom... didn't make me feel too good about the food...
Overall it gets a big "ehh"
author: ruby r.

description:
went here on a busy Sunday morning.  Lots of other brunch-ers but the wait was not bad at all.  15 minutes or so.  

ordered the farmer's breakfast.  scrambled eggs were dense.  dessicated sausage patty needed salt (in fact, I had to liberally salt my whole plate to bring it up to my taste).  I do admire the fact that they tried to make their own sausage patty tho.  potatoes also needed salt although they did have a pretty good flavor and the texture of the spuds was right on...that hard to reach equilibrium of creamy but firm.  toast was terrific.  

the saving grace?  I really like the vibe.  waitress was terrific, it had a nice buzz and the coffee, for whatever reason, was quite good.  

i would return if i were in the area and friends wanted to go but I would not go out of my way to eat here.
author: Mike C.

description:
Hungover and woke up too early? Go to Kate's

Enjoy some Dr. Dre while you rehydrate and get some greasy food in your stomach.

The Flanched Farney Garney breakfast sandwich + Biscuts with sausage gravy will send you right back to bed.

The waitlist usually starts around 11am
author: Jason N.

description:
What is there to say about Kate's Kitchen.  It's in a pretty quite area when ever I go there which is usually like Sat or Sun mornings for breakfast or brunch.  Try to get there when there is not that big of a wait but usually it's not too bad.  God knows I hate waiting!  Anyways, I've eaten here I'd say about a dozen times and every single time it was a good experience.  The service is great, not too over bearing with being available when needed.  Even when there was a bum in the restaurant, the staff was polite and treated him as anyone else.  Too bad the bum did not pay but still, little frustrated the staff was but no ill-will to the bum.  
Lets get to the nitty-griddy of it.  The food has always been right on it's mark.  I did not think I'd be into the corn meal pancakes before I tried them.  Once I did, I was hooked.  Eggs, hash, and everything else comes out as I'd would want them.  Really can't say anything bad.  The coffee, well, it's like any other dinner, it's so-so but that is not a big deal for me as the people and most of all the food is great.  One of my most favorite places to eat and even after a dozen times, I'm always coming back for more.
author: James H.

description: Cute quaint cozy. Great huge plate of hash. Good company too!
author: Emm C.

description:
Kate's Kitchen is a wonderful restaurant when you are in a breakfast mood. (Great for days when you wake up with a hangover.)The hush puppies are great with the nice honey butter.

I love the mountain of corned beef and hash. It literally melts in your mouth. The chocolate pancakes stuff your tummy to the brim.

I doubt anyone in the world would leave this restaurant without a smile.

The prices are cheap, the food is wonderful and the service is always great.

In the mood for breakfast? Go to Kate's Kitchen. Don't think about it, do it and you will thank me later.
author: andrew k.

description: Been too this place too many times to count. Every time I try something new, and every time it has been great. Look forward to many more Sunday brunches.
author: Graeme L.

description:
Meh.
Those biscuits are WEIRD...not too tasty...just weird...and the gravy is weirder (and lumpy). Sort of tough to ruin biscuits and gravy, but Kate's manages to do it. What a shame.
Maybe I ordered the wrong thing, but I don't get what is wrong with your taste buds, San Francisco. I will go back one more time to try a bacon waffle...but I'm not expecting much.
author: Kathryn E.

description: Really fantastic place. Great reasonably priced AM comfort food with very friendly staff. I had the Flannel corned beef hash with egg. Although yummy I wished I had ordered the blueberry pancakes or buttermilk bisquit I see on the table next to me. Large portions so come hungry.
author: Mike G.

description: Great food, great prices and great service! We had the Irene's special wrap with bacon, eggs, avocado etc and pumpkin chocolate chip French toast. Both were super delicious! Our server, Anna, was a ray of sunshine too. We will definitely go back!  Try it out if you are in the area, your taste buds will thank you!
author: Maggie M.

description: Decided to go to Kate's after looking at the menu online and seeing all the reviews on yelp.  The food was OK, not amazing, not bad just OK.  I was extremely sad to see that what was online was not on their menu for that day.  I ordered the egg sandwich with the egg over easy and the egg was medium...Normally it wouldn't bother be all that much but considered that was literally the only thing that had to be cooked it was a tad disappointing. With all the amazing brunch places around here, not too sure I will return.  Sorry Kate's
author: Adrienne B.

description:
Eveytime I've been here I've been sorely disappointed.  The food is tasteless bordering on ok, and the sceene is endless. My friend described this place as having pretty food, and that was about it. 

It falls into my group of over rated, over crowded San Francisco breakfast joints.
author: Geoffrey P.

description:
AVOID AT ALL COSTS

I hate to give such a low rating to anything but in the case of Kate's Kitchen it's well earned.

First off, the sound system- if one can call it that- is played far too loud. The other thing completely inappropriate is the way the employees used the sound system as a personal DJ device constantly flipping through their favorite Guns 'n Roses, assorted heavy metal and yes, even Carlos Santana. I thought a restaurant was for the customers not the employees - well not at Kate's, you have entered a zone where the inmates run the asylum. Ask yourself, do want to listen to Axel Rose at full tilt boogie at 10:00am in the morning? 

Perhaps I'm spoiled but the food - at least what my companion and I ordered  - was either mediocre, poorly prepared or both. Having been spoiled by Rick and Ann's and Cafe Fanny (both East Bay establishments) perhaps I was expecting too much for breakfast fare.

I ordered the "oatmeal" although I cant remember what they called it with their particular Kate's Kitchen nomenclature. When it arrived it looked good enough with ample fresh strawberries and bananas but was fatally wounded by the fact that it was not fully cooked. How you screw up oatmeal is beyond me but Kate's has perfected it. In my book if I can cook something better than the "chef" you loose all credibility as an eating establishment. And if you screw up something that needs 4 minutes in a microwave or half an hour in a crock pot you need some remedial cooking instruction - and pronto.

My friend ordered a "fruit and granola salad" again apologies to the wizard who came up with the cutesy Kate's name. It was just OK. Although I question the wisdom of putting melons and granola together.

As mentioned elsewhere the wait staff was hipper-than- thou but one should expect that on Haight.

If you can't tell by now, I just don't see any reason to patronize Kate's unless you'd like an aural assault and disappointing food served up with attitude.
author: Ty A.

description:
3 words.
French toast orgy.
'nough said.
author: Star M.

description:
A distant second to Mama's when it comes to tastiness.

BUT...

The place gets the same number of stars in my book because

1) Portions are HUGE.
2) The wait isn't as long during the breakfast hours.

Fresh fruit and oatmeal/grains aren't the hardest things in the world to add to an order of french toast but it's definitely an undervalued addition they bring to the table (literally and figuratively).
author: John Y.

description: I wasn't overly impressed the first time I went to Kate's Kitchen, but they're a block away, so I tried again. This time I got the Flannel Hash, which was very good and served in a generous portion.
author: Arram S.

description: Kate's Kitchen has been my favorite brunch place in San Francisco for the last 14 years, until my last visit. Now, it's just pretty good, not the best. I'm disappointed that the corned beef hash is now made up of  veg and meat cut super small, a smaller portion of it, and not nearly as tasty as it used to be. I used to dream about the large, obviously, fresh vegetables they used and the large cut pieces of beef. Excellent! Now, they're hiding the old veggies by cutting them up small.
author: Nina L.

description: Great place for breakfast, although it is a place for gorging. The cornmeal pancakes and french toast are great, but don't plan on eating again for the next week or so. Used to come here regularly when in town, but I found it to seriously hamper ability to eat for all other meals to follow, thereby causing an unacceptable opportunity cost. Still, one of the top choices for breakfast, and probably the top choice in the neighborhood.
author: Art K.

description:
Yessss!  Finally, great brunch in my neighborhood...well, sort of.  I live in the Alamo Square district and have found it to be lacking the breakfast department.  There's some okay stuff on Divisadero, and okay stuff in Hayes Valley, but nothing great.  Thankfully, all it takes is mustering up enough hung over energy to get over that hill and down into Lower Haight to Kate's Kitchen.  A friend enlightened me recently and I now feel at peace with my Sunday mornings.  aaaaaah...

The food:  fantastic.  Putting yogurt and granola on french toast is freaking BRILLIANT!   

The coffee:  superb!  yes!  all too often good brunch comes at the sacrifice of good coffee, but not here.  it may not be Blue Bottle but whatever they have, they know how to brew it right.  

The service:  delightful!  very friendly, very fast. 

The wait:  not nearly as long as I had feared!  we arrived at noon on a Sunday-- prime brunch time-- and despite a rather large crowd out front I'd say we were in and seated after ten minutes.  can't complain about that!  

Yay!
author: Daniel B.

description: Been here several times, but the past few visits Ive left feeling annoyed, and this morning was the last straw, we wont be back. It's always busy, which should mean its good, but they never have enough servers. It took 20 minutes for ours to come take our order, and when he bought our order he forgot to give us any silverware, meanwhile were waiting to get his attention again and our food is getting cold. Throughout this, i asked for coffee, once, twice, and the third time, as were finishing up, i interrupted him wiping down a table and instead of apologizing for basically ignoring me twice he just said "I'm aware." Walked off and finally got the coffee. Unapologetically bad service, and the food is just whatever, nothing special, maybe its better when you can actually eat it before it gets cold. Forget this place, there are too many good restaurants in SF to waste your time begging your server for coffee and silverware.
author: Jack P.

description:
This place is great for brunch if you're starved and want a plate load of wholesome, homestyle cooking. The sausage patties are the best I've had in town (interesting seasoning), the homefried potatoes are delicious and the coffee is really strong.
 
They do a good, no-frills french toast too, which I would recommend if you don't fancy all those potatoes and onions.  

They loose a star for once serving me poached eggs in a cereal bowl! How hard can it be to put them on the muffin, so I don't have to awkwardly fish them out with a fork and make a right mess in the process?
author: Chris T.

description: What happened to kates kitchen? I live two blocks away and have eaten at kates about five times. First three , good;  last two times - not good. Hash browns tasted like fish or old oil, not good. Last omlette was weak. Biscuit was hard like rock. Oh well, it was good for a while... Mike
author: Michael Y.

description: I am a little bit of a brunch junkie, and I would definitely recommend trying this place. You are going to have to wait in a line because it is a smaller but cozy establishment. The wait can be 20 minutes and onwards but let's keep in mind that it's the city and this place is totally worth it. They serve a good coffee called chicory, different and good. Also, their food tends to be on the heavier side, so if you eat here you're not exactly going to get a lot of work done later. I love their cornmeal pancakes, and they serve real maple syrup which is amazing. Real maple syrup is delicious, and completely changes the typical pancake experience. If you are looking for a very hearty, and home cooked feel, then you will love this place.
author: Sundeep G.

description: Despite my earlier claim of not returning to Kate's for breakfast, i found myself there once again today, mostly because i didn't want to make trouble for my friend who suggested it.  Once again the pancakes were pretty good, the coffee fine and the service good.  But oh that sausage, those potatoes, that breakfast sandwich, none of then were very satisfying.  Kate's seems fine for a quick local breakfast, but I'd rather cook for myself.
author: Adrian L.

description:
I kept hearing this place referred to as "soul food." So let me just clear something up: serving coffee with chicory, while yummy if you're into that sorta thing (i am), does not a soul food joint make.

Also it's good to know if your rolls have gone moldy, so you can avoid serving them to customers. Yeah i know, shit happens. But in the broader context of this place sucking, i figured it was worth a mention.

Now, i'm told that their French Toast Orgy is amazing. But i don't really like tons of sweet stuff for breakfast so i have not been able to verify this. I tend to go for the simple breakfast: eggs, toast, potatoes, and coffee. And they still manage to find room in there to get my order wrong. Also their potatoes are sorry as hell.

Of course, when your neighbor who grew up down the street says "That place isn't that good, they messed up my order, and it's overpriced," you should probably just take his word for it.

One star for the chicory, one star for everyone who said "Dude you can't talk shit until you've had the French Toast Orgy." And i really think i'm being generous.
author: player z.

description:
