Kate's earns 4 stars because the food is dynamite and fairly reasonably priced.  The orange spice french toast is delicious(and don't let the name fool you, it tastes nothing like oranges), and the bacon is pretty great too.  

However, the service often leaves something to be desired.  In both of my last two visits, items I ordered or asked for were never brought.  I can only remember ever seeing one server there at a time - usually the same girl - and she hasn't seemed very enthusiastic to be there recently.   Also be prepared to deal with a crowd - especially weekend mornings.

All in all a good place.  And if anyone cracks the bizarre code on the wall, let me know, won't you?
author: Mike S.

description: Great place.  There is a wide variety of vegetarian food and an interesting mix of ingredients.  I love places that try new things and this is one of those places.  I definitely encourage a visit!!
author: Happy Mama M.

description: I had sausages, a biscuit with homemade jam and unfiltered apple juice. Everything was tasty. Prices are very reasonable.
author: Mark F.

description: Pretty much everything on the menu here is delicious from the fruit orgy to the farmer's breakfast. Staff is always nice and playing good music. Get some hush puppies to start. Not the cheapest breakfast in SF, but definitely one of the best.
author: Scott L.

description: breakfast might be my favorite meal.  I like this place, it's not the best breakfast joint, but it's good enough.  i had the hash and that was pretty darn good.  hahaha hash...
author: christopher h.

description: i hate their waitresses, rude and not very helpful, also they include the tip on your tab which is also rude, why would i want to give someone a tip for being snobby.
author: Luis A.

description: Decent breakfast hole -- just grungy enough to be interesting and the food has enough yum in it to keep those lines forming for weekend brunch after how many years?? If you're hungover and need to pay homage to the grease gods, Kate can hook you up. And I mean greasy in a good way.
author: Gregor G.

description: The food was okay, nothing spectacular, with some of the positive reviews I was really hoping for something a lot better. The menu had great descriptions that over hyped the food. I ordered the M&M sandwich (meatloaf sandwich), presentation wise it looked great with the plate fully covered in food for an expected hearty meal. The consensus with 4 other of my friends during this meal was that the food was not very well seasoned. Everything was a little bland, even our biscuit and gravy. the food is not bad by any means, but I've experienced better.
author: T M.

description: I hate to be ants at a picnic, but I think Kate's is over-rated and totally not worth waiting in line.  The interior is cutesy. The food is just okay.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Ok, So my first review is Kate's.  Awesome! I've been there several times over the course of 4 months and have had everything from the Bkfst sandwich to the French toast orgy.  So should you ever be in the Lower Haight, you should definitely stop by.  Food Great, and the waitress actually turned me on to an artist for some ink that I needed to finish up.  Just a very cooool place to eat and relax.
author: Chris A.

description: Cute little hole in the wall off Haight.  I got the corned beef hash breakfast - which was super yummy - but not enough corned beef!  My bf got the "meat" omlette and had maybe 2 pieces of sausage in it.  He wasn't too impressed with the place - but - he isn't the one writing the review!  :)
author: Katie V.

description: Love this place, the cook actually knows how to "cook" the food, unlike most every other breakfast spot in this city, everything tends to be on the dry side which i prefer, no runny southern eggs tyvm. Their Hush Puppies are to die for as well, if only they would let me make a 1/2 order of them as a regular breakfast and a full order of HPs is just too much food.  As for the staff, i have never had a problem with them, but i could see how i might have problems if i was expecting a five star breakfast, (i'm gonna go out on a limb here) and guess that the people who panned Kates are just too yuppyish or just expecting way too much for too little,,,like most marinaites... I on the other hand have "made due" with less than perfect cituations my entire life, so kates is no problem for me, please note the name is "Kates Kitchen" not the buffet at the "Hilton". You are in the haight, get used to it.
author: Brian H.

description: A generally good breakfast and lackadaisical service is a combination not necessarily worth waiting in line for more than fifteen minutes, especially in this decidedly unattractive shabby section of the lower Haight. Portions tend to be oversized, but the typical fare here - pancakes, omelets, hush puppies, and the like - doesn't travel well in a doggie bag, so go only when hungry enough to clean your plate.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I ve been regular at the Kates Kitchen for years. Quick, well done grissy spoon really worth it. The menu have really good breaky combos also sanduich. Every thing under $ 9 dollars make Kates Kitchen one of the favorite Breaky spots in town. The 12 cereal mixes oatmeal its my number one, besides the Big guy breakfast its made for hungry people like me. I like Kate's between 8 am to 10 am so I can take advantage of the Farmer's special, early birdyyyyyy.
author: Alex M.

description:
i went again this year.  right before closing non-the-less.  horrible for me to ever do that to a restaurant.  i know because i don't like when they do that in my shop.  any who i ordered their hush puppies.  like always.  and still as yummy as i remember.  sweet sweet butter dripping from every inch of fried cornmeal.  mm.. mmm.. mmmmm.  their coffee, eh, i could have had better.. but beggers cant be choosers.  i wasnt going to walk in with some other persons coffee thats a big no no ... 

i also had the greek scramble and that was yummy a little to much asiago cheese which made the eggs runny, which is kinda gross when you scramble eggs....  everything else good... not what i remember but till good...
author: Lety M.

description: Well, we've tried Kate's twice now and that will be that. We gave it a second chance because we figured with all the talk, we must have had a bad experience the first time. But, no, the food was again just bland to mild. The atmosphere is ok and so is the service. Bottom line is that there are plenty of other, better brunch places...and ones that take plastic.
author: John B.

description:
i've only eaten here once (last week). i ordered the 'big guy's' breakfast ... or whatever it's called. it came with 2 huge pancakes, potatoes, sausage, bacon, and 2 eggs. 

the positives: large portions (a very good thing when your a hungry hungover pig like myself), and the bacon and sausage were pretty good. 

the negatives: my 2 huge pancakes were pretty cold and on top of that, the syrup was also pretty cold ... like as if the server just grabbed it out of the fridge, which then made my pancakes even more cold. also, my potatoes were also pretty lukewarm and they were a little overcooked with some narly pan scrapings mixed in with my mound of potatoes. and finally, this place was oozing with bohemian / uber hipster vibes - sort of like boogaloos is. 

i need to give this place one or two more tries before I completely write them off. maybe i went there on an off day.
author: James J.

description: Like the late, great Kenny Rogers once said, "You got to know when to hold 'em, know when to fold 'em, Know when to walk away and know when to run..." Just kidding, Kenny's not dead. But with Kate's Kitchen, it's all about playing your cards right. Don't go at 11am on a Sunday and then bitch about the wait. Don't complain about the pancakes if you weren't smart enough to order the hush-puppies. Revel in the diner coffee and hollering kitchen staff. This isn't Ella's in freaking Laurel Heights. It's a block up from the projects. Love it or cross your name off the clipboard, cuz I'm hungry.
author: guinevere h.

description:
I'm giving two stars because our first visit was pretty good.  veggie scramble and biscuits were delish.
but today was another story.  waitress dealing with some homeless guy who had no money and she was kicking him out.  so I waited until she was finished with him, hoping to get sat.  she looked right at me, then turned away.  hmmmm, I thought.  am I supposed to seat myself, or wait?  luckily she realized I was waiting to be sat and helped me, with an apology.  
the food today was really disappointing.  hubby had corned beef hash with big fatty chunks of beef and gristle.  not delish.  
I had whole wheat french toast with strawberries and bananas.  the chef did not soak the bread.  at all.  I cut into my french toast, and other than where it was grilled on the outside, it was dry, dry, dry.  and there wasn't enough maple syrup to make up the difference.  chef:  you have to soak the bread.  for an appreciable amount of time.  I wound up with a plate of whole wheat toast.  not french toast.  
our server took our order, delivered our breakfast, then slapped the check down without a word.  
won't go back.
author: char s.

description: Seems like a good place if you live in the neighborhood, but it wasn't worth my trip. The veggie gravy was more like cream of mushroom soup and everything else was just ok. Glad I ventured over to try something new, but can't say I'll be back...
author: Shal J.

description: Okkkay! I'm not a big pancake person, but when I eat them I like them to be included in a "Big Boy Breakfast" with powdered sugar, maple syrup and fluffier mountains of pancakes that Aunt Jemima herself couldn't even possibly attempt. Homefries, bacon, and sausages, OH MY. Lions and tigers and bears, hell no. Food glorious food, so scrumptous and greasy. Food glorious food, bring yourself a big ass hangover stomach because Kate's will pack your tummy tight and send you to the moon.
author: Braden B.

description:
i love this place with a passion.

 the walls are covered with things like "URAQT" or "CUL8R" to figure out, which gives you something to do while you're waiting for your food. 

it's down right hearty greasy homestyle food. huge portions and made to perfection. 

i definitely recommend the corned beef hash. huge chunks of corned beef, none of that shredded BS. 

and the french toast ORGY is just ridiculous. share that with someone. six slices of orange spiced baguette with fruit, yogurt, granola and honey. if you can finish that by yourself then i applaud you. i guess in that case i applaud myself because i can definitely finish that off on my own.

just GO. stop sitting around reading these reviews. just GO now.

p.s. the coffee is good too.
author: Regina C.

description: You know, everyone loves Kate's, and I can *kind* of see why. It's got a cozy feel and it's cheap, but the food hardly justifys the wait. The flannel hash is good, but the regular potaoes never thrilled me at all, and the farmer's breakfast is the same eggs and bacon you can get anywhere. Everything else here is ok, but I never understood why people wait outside for a table when there are other places nearby that have less of a wait. If it was larger inside and less of a hassle, I'd give it 4 stars, but as of now I only eat there if I happen to be up very early in the morning so I can avoid the rush.
author: Tom H.

description: This is a solid breakfast place with lotsa carbs and huge portions.  The hush puppies and pancakes are terrific, and the other stuff's OK.  I'm not a big fan of the coffee, but they are generous with the warm-ups.  (A full cuppa so-so joe sometimes beats an empty cuppa the good stuff.)  I'd give this place 4 stars if the service was a little more snappy.  It's best to go on a weekday and avoid the wait.
author: Andi T.

description: This used to be the best corned beef breakfast in town. I could cry.
author: patrick g.

description: I love Kate's.  The pancakes especially are to die for, and the scrambles are pretty darn good too.  Minus one star for the wait, the boring potatoes, and the loud music coming from the kitchen.
author: Christina D.

description: I would give Kate's Kitchen between 3-4 stars based on what you order.  I went with a group of friends the other day and ordered a specialty omelet as usual. It was tasty and the potatoes are also great.  The potatoes at Kate's are more unique and better than Mama's in North Beach.  My friends had a variety of choices from eggs to pancakes to corn beef hash.  The basics such as pancakes, eggs, and biscuits were just average but if you have a specialty omelet, specialty scramble, corn beef hash, or french toast, you won't be disappointed.
author: Josh K.

description: Love this place. Big portions, affordable prices, and very homey. But don't like the line. Get there early to avoid the lines on the weekends.
author: Vivien C.

description: French Toast Orgy... oh and the biscuits.  That's all I have to say. YUMMY!!!
author: Alejo J.

description: Such a great find! Yes you might have to wait for about 20 to 30 minutes on the weekend - but go grab a cup of coffee across the street at Cafe International, and just enjoy the fact it's the weekend! For under $10 I got the BEST breakfast sandwich - the Lauren Special - 2 sunnyside up eggs on a kaiser roll with aioli, tomato, onions, cheese, avocado, and meat (I passed as I am a veggie) plus home fries. Throw in a coffee and some friends - that's the recipe for a great weekend.
author: Gina M.

description:
Service here was always casual, but I've always considered that part of Kate's charm.  On my last visit, however, it was downright disrespectful.  We had to ask for everything -- water, extra coffee -- while in the past those things were offered automatically.  

The young lady who has always worked the weekend early morning shift was helping herself to what looked like a 3,000 calorie breakfast of an omelet and ice cream, while completely ignoring  her customers.  One gentleman walked in, stood in the middle of the room looking lost, just to have her wave him to a table, while chewing at the same time.  He turned around and walked out and I can't say that I blame him.

Other staff members were engaging in behavior, in full view of the few patrons that were there, that was downright unsanitary.  One guy was eating his own breakfast while arranging food on the plate for a customer.  And yes, he did put his hands in his mouth before touching the customer's food. 

I couldn't help noticing how empty the restaurant was for a Saturday at 9am.  I'd never in all my years of going to Kate's saw the place this empty.  I don't think its the economy, I am pretty sure its the ridiculous attitude of the servers.  I know I won't be back and I will contact the health board about their sanitary indiscretions.
author: A. B.

description: This place is my weekend breakfast spot! When you find yourself hungry, or maybe a bit hung over, its worth schlepping yourself out of bed and getting your name on the door list at Kate's on Height. You have to start with the Hushpuppies and honey butter.  Then Go for the Lauren Special -Bam! Done!
author: Luc S.

description: I ordered a small and basic breakfast, but was not overly impressed. The English muffin was good, but the homefries were greasy. The strawberry jam was great, but the jalapeno too sweet. The neighborhood isn't the best, but the bus is nearby. The service was friendly and the atmosphere was comfortable. I did feel that this was nothing special, with the exception of the strawberry jam.
author: Lauren G.

description: Kate's Kitchen is one of my favorite brunch spots. The pumpkin french toast is to die for and even though it's on the "Specials" board, it's been available every time I've been in. The cornmeal pancakes are a nice twist to this breakfast staple and their coffee is great. The homefries leave something to be desired. Definitely a cozy space so if you're uncomfortable being seated too close to neighboring diners then this might not be the place for you. The wait staff is friendly but it wouldn't hurt if they stopped by to check in more often.
author: Katie R.

description: Other than the ft orgy novelty (really just a monolith of drenching dollops of things like orange zest, granola and yogurt. A first grade arts and crafts project meant for 12, consumed by 1), everything here is a composite relic. With this city, these kind of crowds, the furnishings et. al that somebody in their fold hasn't discussed a dashing animus-less option for those stragglers of americana deceit is just so scope frugal. The message has cleanly pulverized numerous senses. To think squat and gobble was more up my alley inspires insurrection. En garde, Kate!
author: Christopher J.

description: I checked out Kate's Kitchen on Saturday morning, and there wasn't a huge line either.  Score.  I ordered the French Toast Orgy, and was heartily surprised when they brought out my plate, which towered with food.  Now, I'm a big eater, but I couldn't eat it all- good news, I think (the remnants made my Monday breakfast at work awesome, too).  The price was right as well- rest assured, I'll be back.
author: M S.

description: Great place for inventive and cheap omelettes. Usually I hate sausage but they worked their own homemade stuff into a great omelette with avocado. Be warned and visit the ATM beforehand. They're cash only.
author: Ellie P.

description: So far .. the best breakfast I have had in the city .. for cheap. I have noticed its a good idea to go for the basic farmers breakfast or the orgy .. unless you havent eaten in the past few days. Service can be a bit drag and slow.. but when the food arrives, its hard to keep a grievance. Go Kate's ...
author: Sav B.

description: Whatever is on that orange french toast stuff...i dont know what it is but i want it rubbed all over me. So good. I love Kate's Kitchen. I also love standing in the street with the other people waiting, so we can be warmed by the sun. its a great way to get to know new people.
author: Dana H.

description: You've got to laugh out loud at the service - its not rude but slightly snarkey.  I liked it.. I did.  And its open early on a WEdnesday morning which when the fog rolls in, you really get the sense that this kitsch diner is the only thing left in the mountain town you're now in - I know where did I go with that one?  Don't ask - Basically, the atmosphere is great and the food, pretty great - try it out.
author: Denmo I.

description: you might have to wait but te food is good and the price is more tan right.  Cheese and herb biscuits please!
author: Rachel D.

description: LOVE this place! It's perhaps my favorite place for breakfast.  Never have been disappointed!  Their homemade jams are just delish!  Definitely an earthy vibe- have all the originals to breakfast but they put their own spin on things as well.  The only 'negatives' I would say is that it isn't the best for groups since it is a small place and the wait can be a bit long on the weekends (but that's anywhere really).  I like this place better than the Pork Store in upper haight.  Kate's is a nice chill place to have a nice breakfast/brunch.  I recommend at least once!
author: Sahra S.

description: The best damn corn beef hash in the city! Quick, friendly, and very filling! I try to branch out every once and a while by getting the pancakes or the biscuits, but I always come back to the hash!
author: Joe G.

description: Every time I'm here, it's because I'm seeing two of my best girlfriends from college, so my visits are under the best of circumstances. Compounding my friends' awesome company are the tender, flaky, warm cheddar onion biscuits that accompany their hearty, filling scrambles and big cups of fresh fruit. These visits satisfy all kinds of emotional and physical hunger and I can't wait to come back next year!
author: Erin E.

description: Cute little place with homestyle food and long waits.  I had the eggs over easy with homemade sausage patties and potatoes.  The food wasn't greasy at all, almost healthy dry, and the sausage patties were different tasting but really good.  But my eggs were a little overdone, more so than the way I usually like it, and the potatoes got a bit too mealy towards the end so I had to dump a whole lotta catsup on it.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
i couldn't decide whether to give this place three or four stars, but ultimately nostalgia forces me to round up.  i don't think the restaurant itself is THAT dirty, as others have been saying, although the neighborhood certainly is.  waiting outside, even on a sunday at 11 a.m., can be a little off putting.  

that said, there are several items here that i positively dig.  the french toast orgy is always good (and HUGE; bring a backup stomach), they have some of the best thick-cut bacon in town, the daily scrambles and omelettes can be excellent at times, and their homemade biscuits are yummy.  you can't go wrong with one of the special fruit-covered cornmeal pancakes either.  and for a diner, their coffee is outstanding.

i also enjoy staring at that enormous painting of the u.s. on one of the walls.  the decor isn't the best, but that wall can distract my eyes for a solid half hour.
author: Jeff W.

description: Okay breakfast spot....the line is not worth it on the weekends though!  Something sets me off with the potatoes here, but other than that I have had pretty good experiences here.
author: ELIZABETH W.

description: We don't go here enough although it's in our 'hood. We went this morning and it was great. I recommend the sweet options (anything with fruit) over the savory options, which are just ok. Their cornmeal buttermilk pancakes are amazing and get their famous for their hush puppies on the side. Also, get there on the early side because the wait can get long after around 10am.
author: Bill R.

description:
this place has been on my "to-eat" list for quite some time but usually there's a long wait. i'm a sucker for cutesy breakfast places like this. the food can be just mediocre and i'll still be a happy clam when i leave.

i got the 'flanched flarny garny' which is basically an egg sandwich with potatoes. i added some homemade sausage to the meal and had them prepare my eggs over-easy. the best part of the sausage was that it was a sausage patty, not a sausage link, so it was easy to add to my egg sandwich! it was delicious and everything was cooked how i expected.

my friend got the 'big boy breakfast' with the cornmeal pancakes and i thought the pancakes were yum but heavy. they reminded me of light weight cornbread.

they seem to have a simple menu, mostly traditional stuff (omelets, bacon, sausage, corned beef hash, etc.) but also seems like they have some specialties as well. i'm anxious to try their biscuits next time!
author: elsie k.

description:
I will preface by saying I have only eaten here once. 
This is in my neighborhood and I always see hoards of people lined up to eat here.  I decided to try and it was one of the worst dining experiences I have had.  I ordered the pancakes with granola and fruit and my friend ordered something with a side of sausage.  My pancakes were soggy because the fruit was put on top and the moisture soaked through.  The food was piled so high that I couldn't put my fork in it without the granola spilling off the plate.  The sausage tasted like unseasoned ground beef that had been formlessly slapped onto a grill and overcooked.  Our wobbling table was centered in the line of traffic so every waitress and customer who walked by haphazardly knocked our elbows.  The wait was long and the price was way too high for the food I ate.  The only reason I even offer one star is because the menu had items that sounded tasty.
author: regina k.

description: I enjoyed my breakfast here a great deal. We had some Veggie biscuits and gravy. It was pretty good. Everything else was tasty and somewhat inventive. It's not just a pancakes and eggs place. I'd go back.
author: Robert V.

description: GET HERE EARLY!  Arrived here for brunch this morning and just happened to luck out.....wrote our name on the list and 10 minutes later, we were shown to a table.  What a simple, creative menu.  The interior was small and cozy, but with great staff energy and a friendly neighborhood spirit.  Had the hash and eggs and D had the cornmeal pancakes.  With the generous portions and some bold coffee, it was a super way to begin a Sun(less)day!    Tell your friends!
author: Grant T.

description: Great no-frills breakfast spot ... good food, huge portions. Might have to wait on weekends if you don't get there early.
author: Michael C.

description: The food is fine but over-priced, and every time I go there (3 times) I always think...why am I not just making this simple meal at home? I mean I can make vegetables over brown rice...... Also, once my friend walked by while I was there and stopped to say hello while I finished my completely mediocre meal. He didn't have a bite, but I was charged 2.50 for "shared plate." Whatever kate's kitchen- I'm going to take my business to Roland's which is right across the street.
author: SJ P.

description:
went for brunch on sunday...waitress was nice. 

my meal was ok. the biscuits and gravy were as nice  as the waitress.

best grapefruit juice i ever had.

i think i should have got the pancakes cause the guy next to me had em and they looked awesome.

i had the red beans with collard greens and grits
too much vinegarness

i think i might have done that thing where you thinks its a good idea to order continental fare...but it never is.

i'll try it again, but for now...meh
author: Alex P.

description: HUSH PUPPIES!!!! So so so good, great BLT, great prices, interesting service, not bad, not great, a friendly spot. Right above my work so i will be frequently visiting!
author: Rachel L.

description: What a cute and cosy place for brunch! I met a friend here for brunch a couple of weeks ago and we had a lovely time. I had a daily special omelet which was tasty and my friend was really happy with her choice too. It's a great start to a chill afternoon in the Lower Haight.
author: Alexandra D.

description: Excuse my orgasm - cornmeal pancakes - easily some of the best pancakes to date and what a twist on tradtion.  We shared the BadBrains omlette which came stuffed with chicken apple sausage, mushrooms, cheese and all the other amazing fixins.  Try the pancakes and an omlette - plenty of food for 3, but get there quick, they might be line!
author: Jared F.

description: French Toast Orgy...for a few years, that's all I got when I went to Kate's. Plateful of French toast with a mountain of yogurt, granola, and fruit. You just dig in and forget everything else. I recently branched out and tried one of their veggie omelets. Equally as good!
author: Evelyn G.

description:
My favorite meal is, undoubtedly, brunch. The thing I miss most about living in a big city is the ready availability of brunch and the relative adventurousness of a few special menu items therein. The first time I was here, my best friend and I, never having been in the area, just happened to secure parking right in front of Kate's. As soon as I saw the accumulation of people waiting out front and noted the item "French Toast Orgy" on the menu, I knew we'd solved our parking and hunger issues in one fell swoop. 

The inside of Kate's is necessarily cramped, but it earns the euphemistic adjective "cozy" because everyone inside seems to be enjoying themselves. It's also busy, so your coffee cup won't stay as full as you'd like. I'd be wary of bringing a group of more than four. The other key technical aspect is to know that it is cash only---fortunately there is an ATM right outside the door if you forget.

As for the food, I definitely won. Of course, my superpower is the ability to always order the best meal at a restaurant (which I would never give up for something as trivial as flying or telepathy), especially when breakfast items are involved. I contemplated the whole wheat Texas toast with strawberries and bananas, but since I'd been craving corn bread, I went with the more basic cornmeal pancakes. The short stack (with a side) is sufficient unless you are ravenous or are filling the bottomless hangover pit in your stomach (note: corn may not be the way to go there, compadre). Kate's also reminds me of a good hint for breakfast-ordering: when they describe the syrup, and extra syrup costs extra, that's usually an indicator that the pancakes/French toast are a wise choice. You will have to stretch the single serving of syrup they provide, but the pancakes are flavorful enough to stand with just butter, so don't fear. 

Pancakes are best served with some form of porkage, so I opted for the so-described "thick-cut" bacon. I have to say that my Southern roots were a bit offended by the alleged thickness of said pork, but having gracefully handled such situations in many alternate contexts, I set out to enjoy it. While tasty, the bacon was lazily cooked on a too-hot surface: it was near black in parts but practically raw in between. Needless to say, I'm Southern, it's bacon, and so that didn't stop me. In between bites I snagged a couple of my friend's potatoes: sufficient, but nothing to write home about.

At this point, I could have signed off saying this was a delightful meal. I must rant, however, because it is a travesty that such a delightful place to eat would perform the following unforgivable food foul: the highly touted biscuits and gravy were downright vile. The biscuits looked rather instant, and the cheese and chive or whatever was supposed to be in them was hardly noticeable. Less than stellar biscuits can be forgiven (even though Kentucky sense says you should never marry someone who can't make biscuits from scratch) if, and only if, the gravy is amazing. Oh, but no. First of all, Kate's offers both a vegetarian and a sausage gravy. Um, no. Gravy, my friends, is made of animal remnants. "Vegetarian gravy" is an oxymoron. Call it sauce, call it dip---it ain't gravy. Kate's "sausage gravy" (which also merits quotation marks, as such a cruel parody) was more from the glue family, and, sin of sin, *it had celery in it.* NO YOU DI'IN'T. My friend likened it to clam chowder ("um, without the clams, I guess") although it was apparent that the "gravy" was more akin to a veggie dip with perhaps 5 stray particles of sausage in it, and obviously none of the animal juices required to make gravy. Worst of all, it was served lukewarm and was completely cold by the third bite. When we asked the waitress to warm it up, she brought back a fresh serving, which was nice, except that it arrived in a cold bowl and was tepid in nanoseconds. 

So, overall, go to Kate's and have some pancakes. I heartily endorse the lumberjack breakfast, which I've had on subsequent visits, which covers all of your possible breakfast needs. The egg sandwiches look amazing, too, and I'd bet on the French toast. Just stay away from the biscuits and poseur gravy, no matter how tantalizing the description seems.
author: Mary R.

description: 2.5...I've had better, I've had worse.  It was good, but not great.  I think out of all the things ordered at our table, the french toast orgy was the best.  The coffee was really good though.  I think I'd rather go to our old standby, Park Chow, where the food was better and there is hardly ever a wait.
author: Jeffrey F.

description: I've eaten at Kate's a number of times, each time hoping the experience would be better than the last.  Finally, I have learned my lesson.  While the atomosphere is very "Haight" it is just too cozy for my comfort.  The tables are tiny, while the portions are enormous.  The tables are so close together the waitress has to actually lean over your plate of food while serving the table next to you.  The last time I was here my boyfriend had to stand up about 7 times to let the waitress get past.  The wait time is usually really long, and that's because people lazily sit at their tiny table and drink the over-priced coffee for far too long.  Yes, the biscuits are good, and if you like french toast which is like almost a full loaf of bread then you'll like it, but overall, I'm not a fan.
author: Angela W.

description: The waitress was more interested in hanging out and talking to her friends (and even went so far as to eat with them at the table next to us)...however the food was amazing, and I would go there again (preferably on a weekday in the early afternoon so that you don't feel rush).
author: Gregory M.

description:
YUM. Now I know what the hype is about.

We ordered the hush puppies on a whim and were very pleasantly surprised. Seriously, try these. They are made of awesome.

I ordered the french toast orgy. It is a literal mountain of food. You know it's going to be interesting when your dining companion's jaw drops open when she sees it. It's french toast topped with yogurt, fruit and granola. When I ordered it, it never occurred to me that the french toast component and the fruit/yogurt/granola component would be unified. I thought I'd get a plate of french toast and a bowl of yogurt/fruit/granola. I have to say that although I liked every ingredient, I didn't like them together. I wanted to slather my (totally great, and I am a snob about these things) french toast in syrup, which I couldn't do with the yogurt int he way. (Heck, I could barely get to the french toast with the yogurt in the way!) Plus, the yogurt down by the french toast was warm. Eew. Word to the wise: if you are ordering the orgy, order the components to be served separately. Or, just order the french toast. 

My companions were also happy with their breakfasts (egg sandwich, pancakes) and we all left stuffed and satisfied.

I did knock off one star for not having soy milk. I really, really wanted to have some coffee, but they had no non-dairy creamer of any kind. And my tummy just can't handle the milk. I think this is bizarre at best, for such a popular SF place. Added to the list of places where I need to bring my own coffee. :(
author: Kellie P.

description:
look at the size of that pancakes !!
good food, great staffs, -1 for the surrounding & wait
author: Suki S.

description: I wanna go back for more. I went with a big group and everything looked great, especially the egg sandwiches. I had a great omelet. I had to give it a 3 only because the service was really bad. The manager was sweet, but the waitress was awful. She was so rude and I can't get over it. I hope she's not my waitress next time I go.
author: Mona M.

description: They have these delicious egg breakfast sandwich things, and the coffee is great.  The cheese and onion biscuits, though, are kind of bland.  The restaurant itself is pretty crowded, too many tables in a tiny space.
author: Jackee K.

description: I hate waiting in lines... especially hung over on a Sunday morning. But the times ive managed to wake up early enough to beat the lines... I've left with a very happy belly. My favs are the hushpuppies with pooh butter, and any of the scrambled specials... the only thing is that the portions are monstrous. and when I've been waiting in line for 40 minutes for a table, and I'm starving... I tend to way over order. and i never finish my food. if it were a little smaller.. i could bump it up to 4 stars... i just dont like it when restaurants serves ginormous portions. oh and the hash browns... i didnt care much for them either. they were just big chunks of potatoes. my advice is stick with the specials on the board... they are there for a reason (because its the better than anything on their reg menu)
author: Marina K.

description: The French Toast Orgy. 'Nuf said!!!!
author: Eric P.

description: Kind of ratty decor and the food isn't that great.
author: Flora B.

description: WHAT??  Not worth the wait??  Ridiculous!  Kate's is magically delicious, and as if that wasn't reason enough to eat there, the service is good, too.  I've never had the servers be anything but polite, even complimentary, on the many occasions I've been.  Besides, where else can you find a fruit orgy?  And, maybe you didn't notice, but cornmeal pancakes are hard to come by.  Get up early if you can't handle the line, but don't deprive yourself of the best breakfast in town.  If you're lucky enough in life to have managed to avoid to 8-5 grind, go M-F between 8 and 10am for the Rooster Booster special.  Cheap eats!  And really good coffee, too.
author: Kerrinski S.

description: I would say more like 3.5.  I ate there this past Sunday and the pancakes were good but ginormous!  Charming atmosphere is a cool neighborhood.
author: Sarah A.

description: Try the 'french toast orgy' or the 'flannel hash' and you'll leave with a smile.
author: Todd J.

description: The wait on the weekends is fearsome. Last time I was there, the special was some kind of hash mash with cheeses (bleu and otherwise) and sausage and avocado and maybe bacon and something spicy. It was DIVINE. So much so, that I went back the next day- Sunday and had it again! In all fairness I haven't been back since- the lines are daunting - I am impatient.
author: kristen l.

description: I ate way too much but that is per the usual.  Love the buckwheat pancakes which were pure perfection with fresh fruit.  Bacon is large and crisp and eggs are done correctly.  Worth the wait but I wish the tables were bigger to accomodate the huge portions.
author: Jill D.

description: Good but not as good as it used to be.  I love biscuits but theirs are substandard -- they taste like they're old and have been re-warmed.  I prefer the ones at Boogaloo's, but I'm not hipster enough to go there, plus the wait at Kate's is usually shorter.  Can't go wrong with their veggie omelette or scramble of the day.
author: Nat K.

description: Hm, memory of Kate's and my recent trip were incongruous as I remembered it as being so good (perhaps it was b/c I was cracked out?).  Anyhow, this time I went sober and was not as impressed based on my expectations of my memory of the place.  Perhaps it's from the halcyon days of the dot.com and everything seemed better, but it was a decent brunch but not outstanding...
author: Gene X.

description: I have no idea why this place is so popular! It has a line outside of it every time I go past it.  The wait was about 30 minutes for 2 of us and after we got seated they made us move again to make room for a large party.  The food was alright, nothing really special, the corned beef hash was tasty.  Here's the worst part though, the lady sitting next to us had her purse stolen from her table at the restaurant, and they still made her pay!!!  It was pretty mean of them and it completely lowered my opinion of the place!
author: Craig E.

description: The wait is worth it - the food here is goooood.  Unless you're in the mood for mounds of fruit, the secret here is to get the omelette or scramble special.
author: Debbie A.

description: The food is good here, and I would've given it 4 stars if it weren't for the service. Most of the time it's fine, but there's one waitress who's very temperamental. Once, when I tried to pay with a $20 bill, she told me that she couldn't break it. Is it that hard to get change from the bank, people?
author: Babs P.

description: Arrive before 10 and you won't have to wait. Their OJ is surprisingly tart (in a good way - unusual to most places) and their menu is very carb-y. Not recommended for those on Atkins:). Anyway, if you're gonna order the French Toast Orgy (and you should), ask if you can get the yogurt & granola on the side (separately, unless you like the mush)... chances are you won't be able to finish it all & it'll be much easier to take it with you this way.
author: Anika K.

description: This place came highly recommended. I came here with some friends for breakfast, and was impressed by the large portions. The pancakes are definitely too much for one person, and pretty tasty. Other than that, nothing was really superb. A good value, but as mentioned by others, that  isn't enough in this city (with places like Universal Cafe and Chloe's).
author: Dana L.

description: Very impressed with the food there. Fat midwesterner named Steve sized portions. Seating was comfortable for a packed place on a weekday, and the wait was minimal due to its fast turnarounds. Highlights - homemade biscuits and homemade ginger ale. Hush puppies are definitely to write home about. I hear the waitstaff can be a bit lazy, and snotty, but i have had nothing but good service.
author: Mick F.

description: The wait was a little long, but that is because everyone seems to know how good this place is.  The french toast was a must have since you looked around and saw them everywhere!  I had the special, whole wheat with strawberries and bananas..delicious.  Definitely will be back..worth the wait
author: Jaime C.

description: One of the better brunch deals around.  You can get a good sized pile of food and a cup of coffee for about 7 bucks.  The lines can be a pain, but if you can motivate to get to breakfast before 10am, it's doable.
author: Andrew E.

description: I don't like Kate's.  There.  I've said it.  I want to like it; I've claimed to like it.  So what's the problem?  I just don't like the food.  It's not very good.  Bad potatoes.  Really average everything.  Once had a really gross corned beef hash.  Icky.  Plus, there's this one waiter who is a complete asshole.  He just ignores you the entire time.  He spends his time down the block, literally.  People have to go get him.  Best thing about this place is the coffee.  Really good coffee.  Too bad I can't drink it anymore.
author: Coco D.

description: this is one of the best breakfast deals- portions are enormous and it's cheap. If you want to go healthy, try the fruit bowl with granola and yogurt- really good.  And they also have great omelettes and pancakes.
author: Belle M.

description: Decent food, service varies from very good to very bad (depending on who's doing the serving), terrible, hands down, worst coffee I will drink in SF. Fast coffee refills, though - good for that morning fix. Best secret: swap home fries for their excellent fruit bowl. Best before 10am.
author: Blaine C.

description: Kate's popularity is not due to the service or food quality, Kate's is popular because it's a true neighborhood eatery where you can get a homecooked meal at a very affordable price. The interior is loud and active and you are sure to hear some shouting and bickering in the kitchen which is all part of Kate's charm. On a weekend Kate's is packed and there's sure to be a small crowd out front waiting for a table. The food here is pretty standard, ham and eggs with home fries, French toast, omlettes etc. Nothing too fancy, just good old fashioned all American food. Kate's is definitely worth a trip when you just want something simple. They make a beautiful fresh fruit bowl thats worth a trip too.
author: Eric C.

description: Not really as good as all the Hipsters made it out to be. PLus they had a pretty limited selection and it felt like the waitress did not care for us. Granted it was 2:45 and they were closing up, but we still expected service gosh-darnit! I still prefer Eddie's Cafe over this place.
author: Harry B.

description: One of my favorite breakfast joints in town. The short menu is all good. Flanched Farney Garney, whatever that is, is what I want. Berry pancakes. French toast orgy. It's all good. Kate's has 2 main demerits--the coffee is not great, and the tables are only good for 2 people, or you're looking at a long wait.
author: Nato G.

description:
Came here for brunch last weekend with an old friend - one that I have spent countless mornings eating eggs and cheeses in crappy diners on the east coast. I guess I shall never find a wonderful buttery egg and cheese properly done around here... perhaps this added to my disappointment, but the food just wasn't good. 
The good - the daily egg scramble. All sorts of goodies, good portion. Also we got here at 11am, apparently before the hungover awake, so we got seated immediately. 
The bad - this horrid biscuits and gravy dish. Needed seasoning desperately, it tasted like low sodium veg broth with flour. Yuck. Plus the biscuit was hard and tasteless. Also, no espresso. Coffee just doesn't do it for me. In addition, the tables are so darn close together - I understand needed lots of tables for a busy brunch place... but one of the tables was so close to the door that there was only about a foot clearance when you opened the door! 
Much better breakfast places around, I would only come here again if I was magically on the street, starving and unable to walk.
author: amy b.

description: This place is so cute-it's feels like home. The food was ok here-although I've only come here once, my omelette was prety good. They sure do make their eggs extra fluffy, which I love!! You also gota try their cheese & green onion biscuit-it's good! And the service is good too-I would definitely come back to try again!
author: Dessa R.

description:
I ignored the "overrated" comments on here because I'd had a good experience about five years back on the weekend.  Just came back from breakfast on a weekday morning, and jeez.  They weren't kidding.

I ordered a farmer's breakfast with bacon.  They forgot the bacon, the potatoes had a metallic aftertaste (which I can STILL taste after an hour), and (astonishingly) the portions were small.  This would be sort of okay for Denny's.  But Kate's has a big rep, and from what I see they're not even trying.
author: Will S.

description: Nobody beats my grandma's pancakes, but Kate comes pretty close.
author: Yasmine G.

description: By far one of my top breaky sopts in the city!  I'm stuck on the orange spice french toast.  It soaks up butter like a sponge and topping it off with some warm high grade maple syrup is like putting bacon on a tomato and lettuce sandwich.  Hmmm....... bacon.  I also highly recommend the New England Flannel Hash.  This hash contends for best hash in the city for sure with its tender chunks of corned beef love and soft slow roasted potatoes.   the wait can be a drag if you have more than two people.  Oh, and the coffee... oh the coffee!  I swear I can dance a jig about how good their coffee is.  I will burn my mouth just rying to get as much in my gut as possible while I'm there.  It is so strong yet so flavorful.  Best diner coffee ever!
author: Chard M.

description: I came here with great hopes and promises from my buddy. I was promise food that would satisfy me greater than my love for Ihops. My dreams were crush the second I walked in the door. I've tried many cafe's, but this was in my opinion a shit hole. I may have just went at the wrong time, but regardless a business should always maintain a standard. The atmosphere blew horribly from the dark lighting to the waitress who seem like she wanted to kill herself for working. The food was burn and was dry. Service suck, so I shall never return.
author: David M.

description:
it's like... you know when you're waiting outside drooling all over the windows and pointing at people's food and sort of whimpering and innocent customers can't focus on their meals because you're desperately acting out the motions of eating a beautiful french toast orgy and 1,000 cups of coffee?
i want their maps.
the music is too loud for my hangovers though...
author: Lisa M.

description: The food isn't necessarily great, but it is good and it hits the spot when you're craving a giant breakfast.  And there are definitely some things on the menu I enjoy quite a bit.  The french toast orgy is a huge plate of french toast topped with fruit, granola and "love"... oh wait, that was yogurt.  Anyway it's gigantic and very good.  I can pack down the food on any given morning/ afternoon and I barely get through half of it.  The big guy breakfast is good for those of us who have a hard time making decisions.  They basically just give you a little bit of everything which also ends up being a ton of food.  Anyway, come hungry or share with friends.  It isn't gourmet, but it's good for a greasy spoon which is sometimes exactly what you need on a rough Saturday morning.
author: Zach J.

description: I think Kate's Kitchen is like a joke I don't really get. Its sort of on the same level as Taqueria Cancun for me. Everyone else is laughing it up while I sit there kinda chuckling, looking around nervously. Check please.
author: Big W.

description: Kate's used to be so good, I mean it still is for eggs and toast and hash browns. But I got the french toast orgy, which was good except for the fruit that was on it, cantaloupe was out of season at the time and tasted off and the rest of the fruit was just meh. Most of the time Kate's is great, but  the servers were a bit off and not dressed appropriately. If you're into pancakes they are famous for them and they always have different varieties. Portions are huge so you might want to split it with a friend or partner!
author: Gina R.

description: I've been to Kate's a few times for breakfast. I always thought both the food and the service were decent. I tried to go this morning for a quick bite and had a horrible interaction with the server that has made me never want to come back. I showed up rather early after a really early appointment desperate for coffee and and food. It looked empty when I approached so I looked for posted hours which I didn't see and proceeded to walk in. Not one foot was in the door when the server looked up from what she was doing and said, "No! You cannot come in! We are not ready. You have to wait outside". I looked to see what time it was. It was 7:56. Apparently they open at 8. I went outside to wait. At 8:05 I walked in to see if they were ready yet. I was hoping I could just dit down since it was cold and have a cup of coffee. The lady working looked peeved and said, "I guess you can sit and I'll get to you later". I just left. I obviously had pissed her off and I felt totally unwelcomed. I will put up with all kinds of bad food and lame service if the server is friendly. I understand after my tenure as a restaurant employee that things don't always go smoothly. I become far less understanding when I'm being yelled at and treated badly before I've had my coffee. There are many places to eat in this city. I will go to any one of them before I come back here.
author: Jenny L.

description: The fruit orgy was delicious - loads of fresh fruit (I loved the strawberries and melon), with a big helping of yogurt and granola on top.  The granola was pretty bland, but didn't take away from the yummy tang of the yogurt so all is forgiven.  The cornmeal pancake was disappointing - do not, repeat, do not, let it get cold - think eating cardboard.  The coffee was first rate and the service was excellent.   Friendly, fast, efficient.  Our waiter was a really nice guy which always helps elevate a restaurant.  I'd go back for sure.
author: D H.

description: Kate's is a great little breakfast place that never disappoints. I love the whole vibe of the place, and the food is pretty good. The worst part is the terrible, horrible lines waiting to get in for a table. I recommend going very early or very late on the weekends, or working from home and going on a weekday. Get a cheese and chive biscuit and thank me later.
author: Melissa J.

description: This small little restaurant is only open for Breakfast and Lunch and is usually quite crowded, especially on the weekends.  They have some pretty hearty breakfast fare, but I actually prefer some of their lunch items.  I ordered the Big Guys Breakfast with sausage, and the sausage was rather burnt and a little dry.  The Farney Garney fared better, but wasn't spectacular.  I had the Chicken Club sndwich next, and that was quite tasty.  Their pancakes were pretty good, but I like to drench them in syrup and a ran out after the first flapjack!  Bring cash, as they don't accept plastic.  Luckily there's an ATM close by.
author: P. O.

description: I dream of the Pumpkin Cornmeal Pancakes, started off with Hush Puppies and Pooh Butter.  Then roll me out the door because I finished my food and stared at the French Toast Orgy and Flash Farney Garney my friends ordered.  Coffee's ok, service friendly.  As in any brunch place, there's a short wait because it's a small place.  Always a good weekend spot.
author: Julie C.

description: Mediocre food and rude host/seater
author: M H.

description:
french toast orgy ... mmmmmmmmmmmmm  !!

the wait sucks on weekends, and the waitstaff can be self-absorbed sometimes (hey, it's the lower haight, right?), but the food tastes great and there's plenty of it!  

don't try for large groups (5+) on weekends.
author: alex j.

description: The breakfasts are definitely decent, but the portions are way too big.  I felt so bad that I could only eat about 1/3 of the food on my plate.  The sausage  is delicious though, and so are the hush puppies, orange juice, and pancakes.  The bacon sucked.  Very dry.  The service was great for me and even though I went on a Sunday, I didn't have to wait in line..    I agree with the other posters that it isn't the cleanest place.
author: green t.

description:
i love me some kate's!! 
first of all--the farmer's breakfast: cheap, lots of food. 
they have orange french toast...ohhh myy goshhh sooo gooodd. they have aztec scrambles...yummm! 
and you know what? as much as everyone tells me that they've had to wait forever for breakfast...ive never had to wait more then 5 minutes even on the weekends.
author: Joanna R.

description: Waaaay overrated. How is there a line outside on weekends? I thought the food tasted like sawdust.
author: Cate F.

description: High marks for their cornmeal pancakes with various toppings and their homemade sausage. Huge portions. Not so much on some other staples like the biscuits and gravy or the hash. Too, uh, "busy". But given that it's around the corner from my house, definitely a good neighborhood brunch spot.
author: Michael A.

description: French Toast Orgy is quite good (fresh granola!), inexpensive ($8), and of heaping proportions -- split with a pal
author: Tristan H.

description:
Because variety is the spice of life I decided to let this weekend be a Mission Pork Store-free weekend.  Because kicking an addiction is always hard, I must admit, my withdraw symptoms might have made me slightly more cantankerous than usual...but, I do try to be fair on YELP, always.
First and foremost, as I walked in to the restaurant, my first thought was: rough around the edges.  The decorating is interesting (my boyfriend and I spent at least twenty minutes pouring over a full-wall mural of the US and all the exports for each state.  As a proud Missourian I was pleased to see not only were pigs, cows and corn represented, but also the Ozarks.  
The place is crowded, which is good, but it's too crowded: crowded in a chaotic, noisy, un-thought-out way, rather than designed to use space and eliminate noise.  Plus, the kitchen was open, but not in the charming ways of Zuni, more like an elementary school art classroom with a large window so you can watch you food being put together on and off...with the artistry of...the dudes that work in kitchen.
And, to make issue worse, every time the table to our side was served we had to lean forward to accommodate.  I know it's SF, I know space is not of the essence, but planning and thought do eliminate if not alleviate issues of this sort.
And the food.  Actually, I can't lie.  The food was pretty good.  The portions were too big, but that's not a problem, that's a must for brunch dishes.  The coffee rocked, the cornmeal and buttermilk pancakes were a delightful gritty masa texture that was so yummy I got told to keep my hands off the boyfriend's plate.  I was a bit let down by the potatoes--I like mine shredded and deep friend to a crispy sort of hash plate, but these were more J's Pots of Soul-style.
Good for my liver and bad for my point of view, there was no alcohol.  And, I gotta say, a brunch with out mimosa is like a cock fight with out pecking.
My original thought was my final thought: well on it's way, but still very rough around the edges.  Once this place closes in the kitchen ceiling or creates a more unified open-kitchen look, gets a liquor lic. or starts serving sujou and figures out how to make the most out of a small space, I'm likely to give up pork store for good and become a one restaurant girl--but until that day, I pledge my allegiance to the pig.
Oh, and PS: never, ever name anything "orgy" anything.  I hate it.  I won't say it.  Even though fresh oatmeal and yogurt sound amazing on a waffle, I won't order a french toast orgy just like I won't order a chocolate thunda from down unda from Outback.  it won't happen.
author: Jamie H.

description: AS all my friends know- this place is in my top 5 for BRUNCH in SF - course I am all about the French Toast/Pancakes kindda gal.  And, I was lucky enough to be able to eat there with my friend Celly back in May before I moved out to CHI town.  The Portions are HUGH and better to split with someone.  And, if you don't want to wait in the lines- avoid weekends or go after 2pm.  But- for sure get the the pancakes topped with granola and lemon curd!!!!!!!
author: Christy H.

description: The food is not delicious (I most recently had the corned beef hash--corned beef was fatty, potatoes not tasty).  The wait is long.  The coffee is bad.  The atmosphere leaves much to be desired (tables smooshed in to straight rows, seating in the middle of a thoroughfare).  Last time I went there, at 10am on a Saturday, they ran out of butter.  Butter!  I will probably go here again b/c it's real close to my house, maybe to give the egg sandwich a try, but overall I just don't like it.
author: tara w.

description: This place is a fine example of why I love living in San Francisco. Nonchalant goodness. I  always end up getting the big guy breakfast, which would be more than I could eat if it weren't so tasty. If you are looking for fancy, go somewhere else, if you are looking  for simple goodness this a great breakfast spot for you.
author: Riley G.

description: I was really hoping for some fantastic food and all of it had the potential, just lacked something quite basic and simple, salt.  I ordered the pancakes with strawberries while my husband ordered eggs with potatoes and sausage.  Everything looked awesome and smelled great but lacked seasoning, which was disappointing.  I know it is easy enough to add salt to a meal once it is served but I would prefer that it be added while it is being cooked, especially potatoes.  The atmosphere of this place was awesome and the service was great, the food just okay.  I don't think we will go back unless we can't find another place to go which is highly unlikely in this city.
author: Runner G.

description: I love breakfast, and this place severely disappointed me.  First off, no hash browns.  Second, the place is filthy.  I almost always stuff myself during weekend breakfast/brunch, but not at Kate's.  A year or two ago, I remember reading such rave reviews about the place on Citysearch...but no one in my group was particularly pleased with the spot.
author: Lily C.

description: Always a welcome call in my book.  I can eat a flanched flarney garney (egg sandwich) anytime.  French toast orgy is no joke.  Great service, good vibe.  You know those places where you eat the same breakfast food as anywhere but it feels healthier for some reason?  thats Kate's.  only 1 highchair available caused us to bail one time as the daughter was in tow.  Other than that, always a good scene.
author: J.D. P.

description: Cozy, simple, unpretentious, and satisfying breakfast for my brother, which is saying a LOT.  New England Flannel Hash was absolutely savory.  All portions are huge and prices are fantastically low, but get there early...lines form.
author: Jo S.

description: This place has awesome pancakes!  The other stuff is good too, the only problem is the coffee.  The coffee is terrible!  That's all.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
ya know, kate's kitchen is supposed to be the cat's meow of lower haight brunch fare, but i am just not that impressed. i went back here recently with a group of friends, and ordered the sausage gravy with cheddar cheese biscuits. frankly, the gravy was disgusting- totally bland and hardly any sausage. and the biscuits were pretty boring too- very little cheesiness. it's also irritating that they don't accept credit cards.
that said, i have always enjoyed the flanched farney garney (their version of a breakfast sandwich- egg and bacon on a bun of some kind), and their other egg options are pretty good.
author: oona m.

description: Really delicious food, and one of the few places you can get cornmeal pancakes.  But if you come here on a weekend between 11am and 1pm, expect to wait half an hour to an hour for a table.  If you're already hungry when you arrive during these hours, you're better off walking around the corner to Squat 'N' Gobble.
author: Laurel G.

description: After all the great reviews, I was sure that this place would be fabulous.  I was singularly unimpressed.  The food was unremarkable and boring and random.  Atmosphere was fine but nothing special.  I'd pass.
author: Carrie L.

description: I've been spoiled by Brendas and Moulin Cafe in the Tenderloin but this Haight Street breakfast spot is tasty and a reliable source for a meal  when you wake up with a headache and a grumbling stomach one block away. The Fruit Orgy was fresh and delicious. I had a huge sandwich of sausage, avocado, tomato, eggs and cheese. Served with potatoes for around $8 - I'd come back if I was in the neighborhood but I wouldn't travel for Kate's.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Meh. I have higher expectations for a spot that make people's 'favorite breakfast spots' lists. I don't play with that list...and kate's sure isn't on mine.

I ordered one of the specials - the cali-italian omelette. Grease city. potatoes were just ok. Biscuit was decent (but I'll pass on the Veggie Gravy next time). Not a lot of flavor across the board. I'll give it 3 for good service and because there was no wait on a saturday morning. If you're looking for a tasty casual spot, try Dottie's.
author: Jennie W.

description: Kate's serves a good breakfast all day.  Great place to go if you're really hungry or can eat a house. Big servings.  We got the Lauren Special, which was fantastic, and the French Toast Orgy, which was better than average.  Sometimes this place is a bit crowded because of its size, but worth a 15 minute wait.
author: Justin G.

description: I love this place.  As a wheat-free diner, I especially appreciate the DELICIOUS (even to my wheat-eating spouse) gluten-free oatmeal pancakes w/ almonds and bananas on top.  I'm not sure if they are made with certified gluten-free oats, or are made on a dedicated griddle, but they taste AMAZING.  Wheat is the devil!  Wheat-free people rejoice!
author: Roly R.

description: This is one of the hidden SF gems. It's not in the best part of town to find parking but it's worth the weekend frustration. The hush puppies are total comfort food. I like finishing my brunch off with those and coffee. The breakfasts are huge. I love their farmers country plate w/ scramble with green onions when I want simplicity. Scrumptious French toast when I have a sweet tooth. The myriad of ingred in their specialties when I want a well rounded meal. Did I mention the incredible value for your money? 3 can order 2 plates and leave full and content. I hope this place stays around for generations. I take local friends and visitors here :).
author: Val U.

description: Kate's Kitchen has the best pancakes in the city, and you don't have to fork over a ton of money at the end of the meal...just remember to bring cash!
author: birdabee j.

description: Good home cooked food, great murail on the wall, and they were playing great hip hop, something you don't usually find in a diner.  A friend had the french toast orgy, any restaurant that has orgy on the menu can't be half bad, and damn it looked good.  Myself, I had a blt and unlike most places, there was ample amounts of  bacon, and the fruit bowl was fabulous.  Just another great place to eat in the lower haight.
author: brian m.

description: I'm surprised at the # of negative reviews- Kate's has always been very good to me. The service is quick and friendly, the coffee is tasty and strong, and the food is reasonably priced and well-made. And very filling. I hate waiting in line though, is the bummer. Love the US map mural.
author: Jonny A.

description: My boyfriend loves this place. So once in a while we go there. Always packed with Americans. he he. Anyhow for me it's just another breakfast joint. i stick with the basic, scramble eggs and home made sausage. there sausage is not that great but they give you so much food I can't ever finish it unless I was stoned that early in the morning. I took some friends there that were out of town and they loved it. i would go back here again for my man. Staff is nice. i would recommend this place.
author: Ge I.

description: I've been coming to Kate's for the past 6 years, but definitely not as often as I'd like. The corned beef hash - chunks of delicious corned beef, root vegetables (including parsnips) and eggs over easy - is what I measure all other corned beef hashes by (and they all fail to live up to Kate's). The hubby loves the bacon cheddar cornmeal pancakes, which he inhales each and every time. Two thumbs up - bring an empty stomach!
author: yvonne l.

description: This is me reviewing their soup. Soups are always really good and come with a piece of home made special break.  Their waiters and hosts are a bunch of pompous ass holes (1 star).  Dudes...you work at a diner....you not that cool...now fill up my F@#$'n water and coffee.
author: Mickrod S.

description: just went for the second time. took my mom. we got two specials and shared: veggie scramble and oatmeal pancakes w/ bananas and almonds. both were very good. they also had homemade jams for the toast which were awesome. veggie scramble had tomatoes, onions, garlic, spinach, basil, and mushrooms. it also came with toast and potatoes. yum. the oatmeal pancakes were very moist and gooey; very tasty. we also both got OJ which is decent fresh squeezed, not the best i've had. all that food was only $21. so cheap. you can't beat the quality at that price! i highly recommend this place if you want a hearty, tasty, inexpensive breakfast.
author: Geoff B.

description: No Western or Denver Omelettes here. Check the board for a selection of fresh veggied and carnivorous omelettes.   One of the best breakfast joints in town. You will wait, though. Try their homemade herb and cheese biscuits, fruit orgies, and hush puppies, oh my!!
author: David S.

description: i always hear great comments @ this breakfast spot, but i was disappointed when i ordered a pick-up.  the waitress was really in a sour mood, so we felt like we were imposing, and the pancakes were made with a corn meal-like mix.  Correct me if you know the actual mix.  the potatos were good, and fresh.  i may try again at another time.
author: andria p.

description: Awesome French Toast (and great cofffee).  Get there early or you'll be waiting in line (not too early early - they don't open till 8:30 a.m.).
author: Kenny H.

description: Met up with a few friends for brunch this weekend. A friend suggested Kate's as the brunch spot for the week. I didn't expect much from Kate's because this is also the same friend that took me to Lucky Penny's. But I came away satisfied and happy. I ordered the corned beef hash, and they were right, it is the "best corned beef hash in town" (then again I've never had corned beef hash anywhere else in town). The portions are large and everyone seemed full at the end of the meal. I also ordered the tomato basil soup, which was excellent. The ginger ale is definitely not Clearly Canadian. It tasted more like carbonated water than ginger ale. By far the worst gingerale in my life!But aside from that, the place was pretty good. It's not everyday you have the option to order an orgy off the menu (French Toast Orgy).
author: Brian H.

description:
Down home breakfast spot
In the bustling Lower Haight
French toast is the bomb
author: HaikuReview X.

description: THis is my favorite breakfast spot in the city. Lots of people I know love Eddys Cafe on Divisadero but in my opinion nothing beats Kate's variety and reasonably priced menu. So if you want to be amazed at the best pancakes in town go to Kates.
author: Joseph P.

description: After reading that many people thought Kate's was gross and bland, I was a little ambivalent about trying it, but I was very pleased I did. I ordered the farmer's breakfast, my boyfriend ordered the cornmeal pancakes and my friend ordered the french toast orgy, and all of us left content. The prices are also very reasonable and the waitress was helpful. I will definitely be going back.
author: Clare G.

description: Brunch is my favorite meal.  A few simple ingredients can tantalize your taste buds and satisfy your sweet tooth for the day.  We had the short pancake stack with peaches and ginger.  While the peaches tasted amazing, they were only 8 sashimi style slices for 2 gargantuan pancakes.  They amounted to a 1/4 of a peach.  Beware, if you order the Tall stack, they just pile more pancakes and give the same scant amount of fruit.  We also tried the biscuit after reading the Yelp reviews; it wasn't anything special either.  If you want an average brunch, try Kate's Kitchen.
author: Alison B V.

description: Good Breakfast Spot. Good Lunch Spot. Hidden gem in the Lower Haight.  Service was good, but only after we sat for a little while, thats the only reson i did not give four stars.  Their  biscuits: Green onion Cheddar and a little bit of dill, good stuff.
author: Christopher T.

description: I used to live in the Haight and this was my favorite place to go for Sunday waffles, bacon, coffee, etc. My friends and I would stumble in here around 1pm or whenever the line had died down enough to get in. Yummy food. Best chicken club sandwich ever. And little scallion cheese scone thingies.
author: Diana D.

description:
Brunch at Kate's Kitchen is definitely an investment.  Not in money, but in time and stomach space.  Go expecting to wait about a half an hour to be seated, and also to skip at least one or two meals afterward.  

But it's all worth it if you're into solid, simple, American breakfast food.  The scrambles and granola are super tasty.  The pancakes are great if  you're not bothered by the cornmeal batter (and also having to pay for extra syrup servings - annoying.  If they're going to do that they should at least start you off with more than a miserly 1/8 cup ration).   The fruit orgy is definitely not light, but once you dig in you won't care cuz it's so satisfying.   I recommend declining the honey drizzle - it's sweet enough without it. 

The clientele is almost too hip.  I brought my parents here and they were bothered by the loud music.  

The staff is helpful and attentive.

A super place for a lazy, gluttonous Sunday.
author: Katherine G.

description:
love the modern american folk art on the wall.  love the french toast orgy.  love the thick as mud cup of joe.  everything else i've had has been mediocre.  the service has also been hit or miss.
(1 star each for the above loves + mediocre everything else) /2 = 3 stars
author: Eric L.

description:
I'm a huge breakfast fan and this place is hard to beat.  The hushpuppies with honey-butter are amazing and a great way to start the day.  The rest of the breakfast is solid (I usually get the flarney barney or whatever that breakfast sandwich is called), the prices are great and the place has a cool vibe.  

I don't live in the bay area anymore and I miss this place a lot.  The only thing is the line can be ridiculously long sometimes on the weekends.
author: James C.

description: simple, straight up, home cooked style diner. takes cash only. not outstanding, not amazing. but for the cheap price and the full menu, it's not a bad place to go when you're in the hood and looking for something solid.
author: Diana L.

description: Do you like piles upon piles of food?  Have you no fear of carbohydrates?  Then bring your shriveled stomach over to Kate's Kitchen!  I love their sausage patties and hush puppies!  The ambiance is eclectic, homey and unpretentious - exactly the atmosphere you want for early morning breakfast.  The two downsides: 1) lack of parking and 2) this place takes cash only.  No money - No Honey - No Food!
author: Daria i.

description: The food tastes excellent! Though it is a little too much with the chunky bits every where. The only problem is... the french toast orgy left my boyfriend feeling sick all day..and low and behold it made him puke like none other. Which frightens me a bit. So there is a warning for you all.
author: Caitlin B.

description: Hm golly.. what to say.. The fella likes this place, so i guess in a frame of full disclosure, this review will reflect a mean on our opinions to arrive @ its star value (aren't i civilized ;) . There was a wait by the time we arrived : not too late a la Sunday morn.. and so we meandered and caffeinated elsewhere. Once settled inside 30 min or so later, i liked the atmosphere-- homey and charming in that way of being entirely uncharmed with itself. Service was prompt and though one substitution was blotched, it ended up on his plate rather than mine, so at least it wasn't lost entirely. All this said, i'm picky in the realm of "clean eating" and hope to find something of organic, fresh feel on an SF BFast menu. The veggie scram promised the potential of this, but failed to deliver, rather oil drenched, no herbal/delicate dimension and that slip of the mouth feel wasn't olive or extra virgin coconut (i know, toss the health nut from her soap box before she gets too deep..). Anyhow, i'm unlikely to clamor for a return, esp w/ Samovar so nearby (uuuummmm.. egg bowl with seaweed..) but can appreciate the large portions post eve out that drive other more flex consumers of the cooked-oil-genre to its doors.
author: Rachel S.

description: is it over rated? yes. does it somehow hold a mysterious allure leading to long wait time standing on that borderline skanky/alterna-cutesy-hipster block of Haight? yes. is the Flarney Garney worth the wait? kinda. wish that places like this had a neighborhood resident priority seating option, sort of a velvet rope at a nightclub VIP entry policy; i live a block away and have to wait around with people who sign in for a large party then spend their time making endless cellie calls to the rest of their party who are driving around and around looking for parking. gross.
author: Kevin M.

description: Overrated, disappointing, and overpriced. We were all ready for some good "down home" breakfast goodness - and every single thing was a bit "off." My friend had an omelette with bacon, and the bacon had a weird texture - almost like veggie-bacon or something, The omelette wasn't very well made (too fluffy and not dense enough) - though few places make really good omelettes. The potatoes were burned beyond "crispy" and flavourless. Whole Wheat French toast and . . .no butter? What's up with that? OK, the strawberries on the French Toast were good and fresh, but that's just sort of expected in SF. The hush puppies are more like cornbread. The weird funky biscuits are like a dense cheese onion scone, not flaky or light in any way. And the gravy - way gross. Takes a lot for me not to like biscuits and gravy - but it wasn't cream gravy. I'm not sure what you would call it. Almost like a thickened vegetable stock with some pesto added. Very herb-y and green tasting. Not what biscuits and gravy is supposed to be. Gravy is just  bacon or sausage grease with some flour cooked in it, half and half,salt, pepper, and maybe a bit of Tabasco. Why places in SF can't get that right is beyond me. I think it's all these "vegetarian" b&g choices and they just use the same gravy and add some sausage for non-vegetarian. LAME. Places need to stop trying to do these healthy/hippie versions of Southern breakfasts. IT JUST DOESN'T WORK. Don't be a fool and wait in line here. At least go up the street to The Pork Store. Sure, it's more touristy - but at least they serve something resembling breakfast. Or if you must be a hipster go over to Blue Jay instead. They manage to balance the Cali/Down Home thing pretty well.
author: David C.

description: this place is completely over-rated. the food was plain and service was bad as well. i spent $24 with my friend for breakfast and we only enjoy the water, eggs, and the wheat bread. Squat&Gobble (around the block) could've been a better choice.
author: Jeff Y.

description: Perhaps I am biased because this restaurant already has a kick ass name. Arriving around a quarter to 12 on a Sunday, my stomach growling after having gotten back from SF marathon training, I am a bit disappointed to see the dreaded line outside Kate's Kitchen. But then again, this seems to be standard for brunching in the city. Luckily, you can write your name down and then go off to mind your own business, but since I don't live that close, I just sat on the outdoor bench in the drizzling fog and waited for my friend to arrive. We probably waited about 25-30 minutes before being seated at a cramped red checker table cloth covered table. As I had heard the portions were enormous, I opted for the short stack of buttermilk cornmeal pancakes with lemon curd, strawberries, and bananas while my friend went for the special of the day- a vegetable filled omelet with toast and potatoes. However, I wouldn't have known I ordered the short stack when the food arrived (incredibly quickly) as the pancakes (all three of them) took up the entire plate which was at least the size of a pizza. Wow. Now I was indeed hungry, after my long run today, but not hungry enough to even come close to finishing the pancakes. Although it was incredibly delicious, lemon curd and butter drizzling every which way and an abundance of fruity goodness-I probably only managed to finish a quarter of the lot. The omelet was good too- I tasted brussel sprouts and other interesting veggies you don't often associate with egg dishes. In summary, I liked Kate's Kitchen, if only for the name of it, but the food was pretty darn tasty and definitely bountiful.
author: Kate A.

description: holy YUM! today is a rainy, cold SF day -- but the trek out to brunch at Kate's was well worth it! i just enjoyed the corned beef hash ("flannel hash"), which i ordered well done. the meat was delish, good chunks of tender beef. the vegetables and potatoes, and scrambled eggs on top, made for a great party in my mouth. the "dessert" portion of the meal was the oatmeal pancakes a la bananas and almonds. simply amazing. the combinations of flavors and textures was heavenly!  oh, and the coffee was spot-on. i hope you try this place!
author: Meg M.

description: Oh my gosh, I don't even like corned beef and hash, but the corn beef and hash!! So so scrumptious!! My new favorite weekend breakfast joint.
author: Elysha K.
